Title: Five Little Pigs (Hercule Poirot, #25)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
So happy to be back reading Poirot! Every time I take a break in between books, it always feels too long. This one had a very intriguing setup. While it's not the first time we've investigated a crime from the past, this one had a nice twist, where we hear many different versions of the events from the different characters. So while Poirot is putting the pieces together, we can also do our own investigation in parallel. This keeps you invested in the story even when Poirot isn't in the picture, because you have your own story to follow. This plot is pretty complex too, with characters you're not sure if you truly understand or like. Who do you believe? Who is lying? Even later in the story it's still unclear whether or not you'll be able to pick the culprit. Which to me, in the end, was a bit underwhelming. It was really down to two options, and either felt fairly obvious if you were paying attention. With that being said, it was still very enjoyable, with well written characters and a complex plot. I would continue highly recommending Poirot and this book.

Quick hits:
+ Very complex characters. Both the main actors in the original crime were extremely deep and hard to understand.
+ The plots with Poirot solving old crimes are really unique.
+ Poirot continues to shine as always.
+ Storytelling technique was different this time around.
- Ending wasn't bad, but was underwhelming to me.

Overall, Poirot rules, Christie is the GOAT, and if you aren't reading her, what are you doing? 4/5 stars.

Title: Halo: Cryptum
Author: Greg Bear
My Review:
Wow, that's really all I have to say. Even as a fan of the games since Halo 2 back in 2004, I was not expecting to like this as much as I did. I've never been a big lore guy, and to be honest I mainly only remember big moments from some of the games (Halo 3, Reach, and a bit of 5). But if I knew it would have been as cool or as deep as this, I would've jumped in much earlier! What starts as a somewhat non-sci-fi story quickly becomes much grander in scale, and slowly reveals the deeper Halo lore without overwhelming you with too many details too early. The characters are unique, and experience great growth over the whole story. Some of those characters are actually the most interesting part of the book, if you've played the games you'll have some preconceived notions going in, but you see a different side of some of the characters you're familiar with that make them more dynamic. The story went in a way I wasn't expecting and it was cool to see the lore I am familia with poke it's head throughout. I would say my only two real complaints are that the pacing meanders a bit in the 50-60% mark, and the start can take some getting used to. I know many recommend to start in release order and not chronological but since I already owned this, I started here. As a newbie, a took a bit in the beginning to get used to the terminology and descriptions. But if you push through, there's real quality here. I'm looking forward to reading the larger universe! 4/5 stars.

Quick hits:
+ Characters are interesting.
+ The story starts small and slowly becomes larger and more complex over time.
+ The world is built slowly but surely and really pays off towards the end. I'm officially hooked!
- The pacing meanders a bit in the middle.
- The beginning can be a bit overwhelming at first (story of much fantasy and sci-fi, but that's the fun!).

I'm really looking forward to continuing this series, and I'm definitely hooked. If you're a fan of the games, I'd highly recommend. Even if you're not, there's a lot to love here, and Halo is amazing so get into the games too nerd! 4/5 stars.

Title: The Murders in the Rue Morgue
Author: Edgar Allan Poe
My Review:
Even with a weird start that felt out of place, it makes so much sense why this is considered the grandfather of mystery. That start is so odd, it feels almost like another author writing a preface. But once you meet Dupin, it picks up pretty quickly and doesn't stop. My friends know I'm much more of a fan of cerebral detectives over the more modern action detective. I find them so much more interesting and impressive when you have to use brains over brawn. Dupin is this to a tee, and it makes sense why he is the inspiration for Sherlock, Poirot, and I'm sure more. He very logically breaks down the crime into digestible pieces that all fit together into the very unexpected reveal of the culprit. The narrator fits well and adds another nice dynamic with Dupin, much like Watson or Japp. My only real complaint besides the start, and this is how I feel about a lot of short stories, is I wish it was a bit longer. I like to settle into the mystery and have a little bit more flushed out before the reveal. But if you're into short stories, mysteries, classics, or all of the above, read this. It's one of the first mystery novels, and helped birth the genre and golden age detective.

Quick hits:
+ Dupin is an interesting character, who's more approachable than Sherlock but very methodical and logical.
+ The crime was interesting.
+ The reveal was very unexpected.
- The start was very odd and jarring.
- The story ends a bit too quickly for me.

Easy 4 stars, will definitely check out the other 2 Dupin stories. Recommend!

Title: Edinburgh Midnight (Ian Hamilton Mysteries #3)
Author: Carole Lawrence
My Review:
You know you've read something you've enjoyed when you walk away sad or bittersweet it's over. This was a fun one, and sadly seems like the last entry in the series as 2023 is almost over. I would happily check back in with Ian, Dickerson, Crawford, and Doyle again. These stories are rich in historical detail, and the crimes are well written and enjoyable. You won't necessarily walk away with the Christie WOW, but that's okay because they are high quality regardless. This one had a solid crime, that was interwoven well with the larger overarching story of Ian's past. I would honestly say that's my only major complaint: there's not much resolution for the story we've been exploring for 3 books. So I walk away feeling a bit incomplete. It feels like a larger thread is missing. I get that this might just be a period of Ian's life we were lucky to read about, leaving room for you to know there are future untold stories. But for something so important to his character, it feels a bit like a let down to get no real resolution. With that being said, the rest was great. The drama this time around felt a lot more natural, and the underlying decisions and behavior felt a lot more believable. Ian was clearly overwhelmed in this book, and it made sense why he made the decisions he did. The writing and pacing was the same as the other books; all really digestible. If you're a historical mystery fan, I would highly recommend reading this series. It has good historical detail, good characters, and solid mysteries. I'm sad that it's over (still hoping there's maybe 1 more book in the works that concludes the story), but I'm glad I read it.

Quick hits:
+ Characters are well written, and their character growth pays off.
+ Decisions and behavior felt natural and earned this time around.
+ The crime was well written and mysterious in how it related to Ian's past.
- The ending was a bit of a let down. There wasn't much resolution on some big points and it feels like there's a bigger piece missing from this overall story.

I hope we get another book, but if not, I'm satisfied with having read the serious. I'd definitely recommend to historical mystery fans. 4/5 stars.

Title: Fall From Grace: An Inspector McLevy Mystery 2
Author: David Ashton
My Review:
This one was a mixed bag. The writing and McLevy were as good as usual, and we got to see a new side of McLevy we hadn't seen before. However, a lot of the storylines I quite frankly wasn't interested in. I didn't care about Jean's love story or Mulholland's. I get characters need to grow, and I do like some romance in the books I read, but these felt so unnecessarily forced and honestly annoying. Mulholland especially was a love sick puppy who just became a chore to read, especially considering his somewhat conflicting decisions considering his experience on the force. I get that was the point, but it wasn't believable to me. On the flip side, the main plot was interesting, and how it interwove with McLevy's past. The ending was a bit of a disappointment. While there was a major conclusion for McLevy himself, I felt let down with how laissez-faire the wrap up was considering McLevy's sense of justice. All that being said, I enjoyed it enough, but I didn't walk away loving it nearly as much as the first book. I will check out the next book, as this feels more like a hurdle than expectation going forward. If you like historical mysteries with interesting characters, and history, I'd recommend you give this a shot.

Quick hits:
+ McLevy is still great.
+ The main plot and McLevy's past were well explored and interwoven nicely.
+ McLevy's character development continues to be good.
- The side stories or characters roles in the story were overdone and unenjoyable. This is personal preference though.
- The ending felt a little underwhelming and didn't pack much of a punch.

Enjoyable enough, 3/5 stars.

Title: James Bond: Live and Let Die
Author: Van Jensen
My Review:
This is a bit of an odd one. While overall it was fine, there were parts that were good, and there were also parts that felt really un-Bond and had some odd art. I've never read the full on novels but I've seen every Bond movie, and there was definitely scenes from other stories in this one (for example License to Kill). While these may have been nods, or scenes from the actual Live and Let Die, they were quite jarring and didn't feel like I was reading the original story. Bond isn't necessarily big on plot, but I did find the backstory and stories to be interesting and engaging. Keep in mind though, the main driving force was sort of a dud and goes nowhere in the end. The characters were mostly good, with a couple of underwhelming appearances later in the story. The art was solid throughout, but some of the facial expressions were beyond cringe-y. They felt so unnatural and forced they actually took you out of the story. Overall, this one didn't read as fast paced as I would've liked, and it was an okay experience. If you're a Bond fan, there are better comic versions out there (see Ellis), but if you've read them all and are looking for a distraction, you can check this one out.

Quick hits:
+ Main Bond characters were solid.
+ The story starts well, and has good momentum in the first half.
+/- The pacing dies off in the second half.
+/- Facial expressions can be laughable.
+/- Main plot point is a dud.
+/- Secondary characters really vary.
- Tons of inner monologue and text.

So a mixed bag for me, 3/5.

Title: Shadow of the Serpent: An Inspector McLevy Mystery 1
Author: David Ashton
My Review:
This was an unexpectedly awesome book. I love historical mysteries, and I was certainly expecting to enjoy this, but it was much better than I anticipated. I'm unfamiliar with the BBC show, so I didn't know anything about the characters or world going in. But boy oh boy, does this feel like a well realized world. Leith feels like a living, breathing historical place. The characters were complex and well drawn, where you learn little bits and pieces of them but enough ambiguity exists to keep you interested long term. As for the plot, I really didn't enjoy it for a lot of it. Not because it was poorly written! But because it was playing with established history that clearly wasn't real, and apologies, but that stuff irks me. There was a nice twist however that was both unexpected and pleasing that I completely changed my tune by the end! If you like complex characters, good historical detail, with an interesting plot, I would highly recommend. Historical mystery fans in general should like this one. I look forward to continuing with the series.

Quick hits:
+ Well drawn main characters.
+ A well realized historically accurate world.
+ Each of the side storylines and characters were interesting and had some depth.
+ The book read quickly and never meandered.
+/- The plot ended up being rather enjoyable, but if you're a stickler for historical accuracy, a lot of it will bother you. But I do think by the end you'll be happy.

5/5, onto the next!

Title: The Thinking Machine (Library of Congress Crime Classics)
Author: Jacques Futrelle
My Review:
Real talk, I'm addicted to these crime classics. I love short story mysteries, they're so digestible and just pure fun. This one certainly didn't miss. An American play on a Sherlock set of characters. While I didn't think they lived up to that duo (who could?), it was still a fun romp all around. The mysteries are varied and the side characters really flesh them out. If you're into short story mysteries or crime classics, I'd recommend!

Quick hits:
+ Good main characters.
+ The stories were varied and solid all around. Nothing was disappointing.
+ The side characters were fleshed out and felt real.
- There's a lot of the Thinking Machine just telling Hatch what to do. I would have preferred him being more involved.

Highly recommend for class crime fans and short story mystery lovers around! 4/5. Can't wait to pick up the next crime class from the Library of Congress.

Title: A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court

Title: The Blade Itself (The First Law, #1)
Author: Joe Abercrombie
My Review:
A solid start to a new fantasy series. Reading a book or series where you know so much about it, at least so many opinions, is tough. On the one hand you can recognize why its so beloved, but on the other there's these overly lofty expectations that are impossible to meet. So while there was I lot I really liked in this, there's a few things that brought my enjoyment down. That's not to say it wasn't good, it was. Well written, with well drawn characters, and an interesting world. But, in my opinion, it takes a while to get the world building really going, and some of the character storylines were just flat and uninteresting. But the heights this book hit are very high. The dialogue is great, and some of the characters are so well written (for example Byaz) that you truly don't know how they'll act in any situation. That keeps you intrigued in any situation they're involved in. I think if you go into this without spoilt expectations, and enjoy a good start to a fantasy, you'll really enjoy this. There's a lot to like here!

Quick hits:
+ Great characters: Sand, Byaz, the Northmen, Logen to name a few.
+ The world is interesting and by the end well developed. You'll have a better sense of the history and politics.
+ Well written dialogue.
+ The pacing is relatively quick, with only a few chapters lasting 20+ pages, so the story moves pretty fast.
+/- The world building is good, but takes a while to get there. I felt like I didn't start to gain a better understanding from good exploration until the last third of the book.
+/- The ending sort of felt flat to me. The big action scene was AWESOME. But, there wasn't really anything to made me clamor for book 2. That's fine, but usually you're left with some nugget to keep you intrigued. To be clear, not a bad ending, but didn't grab me totally as I would've liked.
- Some of the character storylines were just so meh. None of the characters are bad at all, but I really just could not care about Jezal's storyline, nor Ardee's. The romance did nothing for me, and honestly felt forced and unnecessary.

Say one thing for Logen Ninefingers, say you should give this book a try. It's a good fantasy novel with well written characters and interesting world. While I suspect this series will get darker in the next two books, this one wasn't too grimdark. There's violence, but it's not overly done or gratuitous. Even if the characters are not nice people, they have some redeeming qualities that have you rooting for them. Give it a shot! 4/5 stars.

Also, give me the Northmen and Logen reunion damnit.

Title: Edinburgh Dusk (Ian Hamilton Mysteries #2)
Author: Carole Lawrence
My Review:
This one took me a bit to get through, but that's because I was on vacation in London (which was great)! Edinburgh Dusk was another good entry in this series. The mystery was interesting, and the killer interludes legitimately made my skin crawl at some points (as intended). I felt the side characters this time around were better, and made the plot more engaging. In the previous book it turned more into a thriller because it was less built as a mystery due to the story structure and limited characters. But with the introduction of Arthur Conan Doyle (I loved the Sherlock references) transformed this into much more of a mystery than thriller. That kept me invested in the plot and the characters. So why only 4 stars? I honestly think it's the storytelling format. Due to the killer interludes and the smaller set of characters, there isn't much mystery in who the killer could be, it's all delegation to side characters and little investigation. That makes the resolution just kind of happen with no fanfare because there's so much build up for you as the reader to think about the culprit. To me, this is less desirable than some fireworks as there's no big reveal or the dopamine from being right. But, it's still a good book, and I would recommend for historical fiction and mystery fans.

Quick hits:
+ Main characters are good. The family drama again was a bit unbelievable and forced, but it was more subtle this time.
+ The killer interludes were creepy.
+ The plot was engaging.
- The resolution just kind of happens in the last chapter.
- The killer is relatively obvious.

Overall, I would recommend this for mystery and historical fans. The characters are good, and so are the plots, with engaging killer interludes to add some spice to a typical structure. 4/5 stars. I'll definitely read the (sadly) last book in the series.

Title: Daughters of the Winter Queen: Four Remarkable Sisters, the Crown of Bohemia, and the Enduring Legacy of Mary, Queen of Scots
Author: Nancy  Goldstone

Title: Evil Under the Sun (Hercule Poirot, #24)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
This is my 24th Agatha Christie review. I can't even believe I've read that many so far and that I'll be finishing the series next year! This one sort of surprised me in some ways. For example, I had a much bigger emotional connection this time around. No spoilers, but I just wanted to give Linda a hug and tell her everything would be okay. As always, Christie presents you with a facade at the beginning of the book. You believe you know the characters in the world and their feelings and motivations. But as you delve deeper, you discover the individuals are truly three dimensional. Is Arlena a bad wife? What is her husband really like? You'll discover that truth sometimes is a matter of perspective. Realizing at the end of the story you feel differently about many characters is a testament to Christie's writing skill and great character work. But it's not just the characters we're here for, it's the crime! And this one didn't disappoint. What starts as a seemingly personal and passionate murder starts to change over time. It expands and throws some interesting curves along the way to keep you guessing. Who is the killer? And did the killer's motivations actually match your thoughts? You'll have to read and find out ;)

Quick hits:
+ Papa Poirot, plain and simple. A complex main character who is passionate about justice in his own way, but also a man who cares about others.
+ Character work is top notch. My thoughts changed about the characters as the story progressed.
+ An intriguing plot that expands and changes over the course of the book.
+ A solid resolution, which always a great way to end a mystery.

24th book, and another 5 star. It's been a pleasure to find an author and character who resonate so well with me and my interests. I whole heartedly recommend Christie's work, Papa Poirot, and this book. Easy 5 stars.

Title: The Apples of Idunn (The Ragnarok Era, #1)
Author: Matt Larkin

Title: Edinburgh Twilight (Ian Hamilton Mysteries #1)
Author: Carole Lawrence
My Review:
What an unexpectedly interesting read. I went into this expecting a typical historical mystery: a crime that's solved from classic detective techniques, with some cool characters and interesting world. What I got was so much more. The crime starts small, and becomes more complex as the plot moves. The characters are well drawn, and are all three dimensional. We also get some interesting interludes of the culprit, who acts as a mirror for other characters we know. It felt like a potential outcome for some of their lives had they made different choices. That dichotomy was really impressive to read. So why only 4 stars? Well, the plot itself was good, but a bit underwhelming on the mystery side since we as readers know the culprit but DI Hamilton does not. That may have been my own expectations getting in the way, but it didn't blow me away. However, going into the next book, I'll be expecting more of this style and I think I'll enjoy it a bit more. Besides the plot, I felt some of the moments (especially those between characters) felt contrived. I think for the most part this is because I didn't truly believe them. Some moments of drama felt forced and not something earned between the two characters. That took out some of the experience for me. But overall, this was great. It's one of the strongest and well written historical mysteries with a modern twist I've read. I would definitely recommend if you like historical mysteries!

Quick hits:
+ Characters are well drawn.
+ Historical period feels real.
+ The killer interludes were well done and provided good dichotomy between our characters.
- There was no real mystery, more of a thriller where the main character has to figure it out but the reader already knows.
- Some moments felt contrived to push the character development instead of feeling truly earned.

4/5 stars, I'll definitely continue in the series. Highly recommend for mystery fans.

Title: Murder at the Mortuary (Ginger Gold Mysteries #4)
Author: Lee Strauss
My Review:
I needed a nice and breezy read before vacation, and this filled that nicely. I've read the first 3 books in this series, but it was quite a while ago. I remembered just a tiny bit, but enough is hinted at or described that you could really pick this up regardless. The writing is really digestible, and while the characters feel "modern", they aren't so modern that it's jarring. The mystery wasn't really a mystery. It's quite clear from the start who the culprit is, we just don't know why. So I wouldn't go into this expecting that. If you go in expecting a nice, easy, digestible ride, then I think you'll enjoy it. And of course, if you read the previous books, keep going!

Quick hits:
+ Writing and characters are solid and move quickly.
+ Nice, breezy read.
+/- Some scenes happen in the background (looking at you ending), which is fine but feels a bit cheap.
- There's no real mystery, it's more of a thriller.

3/5 stars. I'll likely pick up other books in the series when I need a quick pick me up.

Title: The Hunger of the Gods (The Bloodsworn Saga, #2)
Author: John Gwynne

Title: Murder at Archly Manor (High Society Lady Detective #1)
Author: Sara Rosett

Title: One, Two, Buckle My Shoe (Hercule Poirot, #23)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
After finishing this I have one question: why are Poirot and Japp not partnered up more? I've been very honest about my dislike of Hastings, but with that aside, Japp and Poirot just have way more chemistry. They bounce off each other in a playful way, and Japp is insightful enough to be a believable partner. With that off my chest, onto the book. This one was a lot of fun! I always appreciate when Poirot is involved from the start, especially when he's uncomfortable. While my socks weren't knocked off, this was still a very good entry. One of the more interesting aspects is that the characters are very mysterious in this one. You're not sure who's acting and who's genuine. That makes for an intriguing twist that's different than most other books so far. The story is similar. It starts small and seemingly simple, but slowly becomes more complex as the plot moves. Maybe that was intentional! You spend a lot of time focused on the characters and the plot, and less on the potential culprit. So, if you like Poirot, of course, pick up the next entry. If you like mysterious characters, with an ever expansive plot, and well written mystery, then grab this. It's not the best entry in the series, but it's a good starting spot. One note, there is some racist and xenophobic language in this one, so be aware of that.

Quick hits:
+ Poirot, always Poirot.
+ A plot that starts small but gets more complicated.
+ Japp is great in this one.
+ Characters that are not as archetypal as you would expect.
- An ending that doesn't blow your mind.
- Some offensive language.

4/5 stars.

Title: The Dark Queens: The Bloody Rivalry That Forged the Medieval World
Author: Shelley Puhak
My Review:
This is the best historical non-fiction I've ever read. Never meandering, never dry, pure edge of the seat mentality from start to finish. A story that I'm so happy I know about, and yet a bit sad was undiscovered until recently. It gives you so much perspective on how many similar stories, and more importantly, powerful women that have been erased from history. What's more impressive than just the coverage of this set of women, is both the expansive years and figures covered. The author also explains many other people of the time, which grounds the world and sets the stage for the entire story. The prose is easily digestible, and you never go down rabbit holes or spend time on tangents. You gain an understanding of the people and their motivations. Most importantly, you just enjoy the ride. I loved every second of this and I couldn't recommend it more. I hope the author writes more like this in the future!

Quick hits:
+ The period and characters are drawn well.
+ The story draws you in and never lets go.
+ The writing and exploration is fantastic.
+ You never spend too much time theorizing, at most it's educated guesses for the unknown.

Read this book! Seriously it's awesome and I couldn't recommend it enough. I hope the author writes more. I need to find more books about women like this! 5/5.

Title: The Good Knight (Gareth & Gwen Medieval Mysteries, #1)
Author: Sarah Woodbury
My Review:
This was an incredibly mixed experience. There were moments of a solid historical fiction, but also a lot of moments that were all over the place and a bit contrived. The characters were a mix of historical figures that felt historical, and more modern feeling characters too which would take you out of the story. I didn't really believe in the romance as well. The two characters didn't not have chemistry, but I never got the feeling there was a real connection there. The writing quality was good, there wasn't moments where the prose felt odd or clunky, and was engaging overall. But frankly, it just wasn't a good experience. The plot meanders many times, and there's multiple moments you will say "what?" out loud when something seemingly odd happens. Personally, that really affects my reading experience and certainly brought down my experience. I really can't recommend this to anyone who isn't already a fan of the author's many series. But that's okay, on to the next!

Quick hits:
+ The plot is interesting.
+ The time period is well drawn.
+ The historical figures felt real.
- Many of the plot points feel contrived. Much of what happens to Gareth in particular is quite ridiculous and unbelievable.
- The motivations of the villain make no sense for most of the book.
- The end of the book and the way one of the characters accepts it is kind of...odd? Like it isn't bad, but seems kind of out of character.
- The real motivation of the villain at the end is hypocritical.

As you can see, I had issues with this book. I wanted to like it, but too much I didn't enjoy. That's okay, not every book is for me! If you like the author's other books, you'll probably like this too. But I'm on to the next!

Author: R.A. Salvatore

Title: SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome
Author: Mary Beard

Title: Sad Cypress (Hercule Poirot, #22)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
A tiny Poirot courtroom drama, what an unexpected change of pace! While I wasn't blown away by the ending, this was very good. Interesting and complex characters, with a story that seems very black and white but ends up deeper than expected. My only real complaint is one I've made before which is that Poirot takes a while to show up. Page 107 to be exact. I certainly was not bored or disinterested up until that point, but the story always lacks that special something until Papa Poirot enters stage left. Regardless, another great entry, and we're on to #23. Can't even believe we're over half way!

Quick hits:
+ Poirot is always great.
+ Story seems really basic at first, but gets more complex towards the end.
+ Characters are well written as usual.
+/- The ending didn't blow me away but was solid.
- Poirot takes longer to show up than I'd like.

If you aren't reading Poirot, come on, what are YOU DOING???????

Title: Bullet Train
Author: Kōtarō Isaka
My Review:
A wild ride that was a bit over the top but certainly enjoyable. This book is filled with unique characters that all have distinct voices and provide so much depth to the story beyond the tension building throughout. The premise starts relatively simple, but Isaka throws multiple wrenches into it that you just buckle in for the ride. Don't worry, there's some unexpected twists that make it a bit unpredictable. From start to finish I was invested in the characters (Lemon, Tangerine, and Nanao) and seeing how it would all come to a head. There were moments that I felt it was a bit too on the nose (see The Prince), but overall that's my only major complaint. Everything else would be nitpicky. The ending was satisfying (even if it was a bit off screen in some cases), which is somewhat contrary to some of the popular opinions. If you enjoy thrillers that have interesting characters with solid tension, I would definitely recommend this!

Quick hits:
+ Great character work: Lemon, Tangerine, and Nanao.
+ Locked room style thriller where the characters are trapped and tension is built over time.
+ Satisfying ending with some unexpected twists.
- Some points were a bit overdone like The Prince towards the last quarter of the book. A couple of times I audibly said "come on".

This was my first Isaka book and I enjoyed it. I would definitely check out his other books, and would recommend this one to friends or those interested in thrillers with interesting characters. 4/5 stars.

Title: The Killer Angels (The Civil War Trilogy, #2)
