Title: Priest of Bones (War for the Rose Throne, #1)
Author: Peter McLean

Title: Of Thieves and Shadows (The Heart of Quinaria)
Author: B.S.H. Garcia

Title: Upgrade
Author: Blake Crouch
My Review:
This was a very solid read. I felt that sometimes the pacing was a bit inconsistent and there was sometimes too much scientific jargon that I ended up skimming. I mistakenly entered this one thinking it was more of a sci-fi thriller, which may have contributed to my feeling of pacing inconsistency, but the end of this book certainly flew. The world was interesting and full of futuristic changes that felt realistic in our own future. Logan was an intriguing main character who goes through a large transformation throughout the book, which feels really earned by the end. His changes felt natural based on what happened in the book, and never felt like something contrived for plot. Crouch's writing is easy to digest, and he does good job giving the highlights of important concepts. This book also had a couple of unexpected twists as well! That made the last 90 pages a lot easier to invest in. I would definitely recommend to sci-fi fans, and those looking for a change of pace from their usual fair.

Quick hits:
+ Characters are good, especially the Ramsay clan.
+ The world was familiar enough it felt grounded, but also unique in it's futuristic changes.
+ The plot was cool. The ending wasn't unexpected, but definitely earned. I don't read much sci-fi and I was invested throughout.
- There is sometimes too much scientific jargon. I think it's meant to show Logan's changes throughout the novel, but it still felt overdone sometimes. So much so I ended up skimming those sentences because I just felt blah.
- The pacing was somewhat inconsistent. There were times a big thing would happen, and then we spent a lot of time at the bottom and ramping up again. Once it gets going though, it goes.

Overall, a very good 4/5 novel. I just purchased Recursion and I look forward to giving that a whirl. I would recommend to sci-fi fans, and those looking for a change of pace like I was.

Title: The Regatta Mystery and Other Stories (Hercule Poirot, #21; Miss Marple, #2.1)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
An okay pass the time read. This one is chalk full of Poirot, with a Marple, Parker Pyne, and standalone included as well. I'm on record that I think short stories are not Christie's strong point. Her talent, to me, really lies in longer books where she can flesh out the characters and the plot. The stories go by a bit quick and the characters and plot end up feeling much more flat than her normal novels. Obviously Poirot in particular is meant to be the ultimate detective, but the reveals just sort of happen in the short stories and don't feel earned. As a reader, we want to feel we have the opportunity to solve the crime even if we can't. With these there's very little evidence given so you lack the opportunity. As I've said before, I think the Sherlock short stories are far superior (with the novels being weaker). If you're interested in Poirot, I think there's better places to start, but if you're already 20 books in like me, of course you should read it.

Quick hits:
+ All of the main characters are good (Poirot, Marple, and Pyne). Pyne was better than I expected.
+ The stories are varied in crimes and non-criminal mysteries.
+ Fast paced.
- The standalone mystery is beyond pointless. It's like 7 pages and not even a real story.
- Reveals tend to just happen so the only real investment is if you're a fan of the main character.

Pretty quick overall even with it being okay. Just a forgettable entry. On to the next!

Title: The Tainted Cup (Shadow of the Leviathan, #1)
Author: Robert Jackson Bennett

Title: The Malevolent Seven
Author: Sebastien de Castell
My Review:
I did not enjoy this book. Until about the 2/3 mark, it was sitting at a 3 star for me, but I didn't enjoy the last third enough that I brought the rating down to a 2 star. There is good to be found here, like the magic system and the humor. But, there is a lot that just didn't work it outweighed that good. For the most part, I found the characters quite shallow besides Cade, and there was a lot of presumption that a connection to those characters, and the characters connections to each other was present, but I never actually felt that while reading the book. You don't meet some of the characters until 2/3 through the book, so how do we have enough time to form any connection?

This book also relies a lot on telling and not showing. We're continuously told how bad the world is, and how bad the characters are, but we barely see that on the page. Just because we're told about one bad thing happening, does not necessitate that the whole world is bad. It's just a giant generalization. An example of this is in how we're continuously told by the narrator that "we're the bad guys". But they don't really do anything bad. Sure, is there death and killing? Of course, but that's no different than any other fantasy books. Many fantasy good guys kill people, but we don't look at them as bad. This made it hard to really believe anything in the story as you're instantly taken out of the moment when something like that happens.

The story is also quite convoluted to me. What starts as a relatively simple premise, gets quickly more and more complicated. This is normally a good thing, but here, it ended up becoming full of holes. We're told that one of the characters is an incredibly good investigator, yet he misses things that should be obvious to provide a plot twist to a reader. That doesn't really work in reality though. You end being completely aware of this happening. The world-building is relatively minimal as well. There's no hints that will be useful later, or planning on what's going to happen. Just magically in the moment the characters figure it out. That means it's hard to invest in the plot, and you feel conveniences are used to resolve the story.

As I said, the writing is solid, the humor is good, and the magic system is interesting. But there was a lot more to critique. I would still like to read Greatcoats, and I think this is more attributed to this story than the author for me overall. Regardless, I would struggle to recommend this to others. On to the next!

Quick hits:
+ Writing is solid.
+ Magic system is unique and interesting.
+ Humor is good.
- Lack of character depth and development.
- Lots of tell and not show.
- Plot development is lackluster.
- Multiple contrivances to resolve the story and plot points.

2/5 stars.

Title: Hercule Poirot's Christmas (Hercule Poirot, #20)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
She's done it again. I don't know how after 20 books Christie still manages to surprise me, but she does! I really thought I had it this time, and similar to the last time I felt that, I got something right just not the whole picture. But honestly that's better, because it enhances my reading experience every time. As per usual, the characters are great, and the story is well written. Similar to the recent entries, the crime seems simple and the suspect pool short, but it slowly gets more complex as the story progresses. As Poirot always say, it's all about the psychology! To be honest at this point I keep running out of words to say. Christie is the GOAT, and she just gets me as a reader. I can't wait to read the next one.

Quick hits:
+ Poirot is great.
+ Characters are varied and feel real. Their interpersonal relationships are complex in this one and were fun to read.
+ The story starts simple and grows throughout the book.
+ Unexpected reveal that had my mouth hanging open and saying out loud "No way".

If you're not reading Poirot, you should change that. She's still at the top of her game 20 books in and I can't wait to continue the series. Easy 5/5.

Title: The Bookseller of Inverness
Author: S.G. MacLean
My Review:
This was a solid historical fiction book. Nothing that knocked my socks off, but that's okay, it didn't need to be. The history of the time period is so rich and fully detailed throughout the book, you'll be wrapped up in it all. While there is a mystery in this book (in that there's a crime and an unknown culprit), it's really a backdrop more to the conflict at the time and the character's journeys. The reason I say that is because unlike a typical mystery, you won't be receiving a lot of clues and trying to put the pieces together. It's a pretty simple mystery overall and the culprit isn't a major surprise. But I don't believe it's meant to be. It really is to spur the character's journeys throughout the book. The problems for me really steam from some of the characters and pacing. There are some really good characters (see Iain), but also some really unenjoyable ones (like Hector). There's also chunks of the book that feel like not much is happening plot wise due to waiting on some character to reveal a new piece of the puzzle. This made it feel like the pacing was start/stop, and that some of the characters didn't have much agency. Even with my criticisms, the writing was good, and I was engrossed in the history that I still had a great time. If you're into historical fiction with interesting history and characters, with a dash of mystery, try it out!

Quick hits:
+ Great writing.
+ The world and history was very engrossing.
+ 3D main character. Iain was so fun to read about and I really felt for him.
- Weak mystery subplot that was predictable.
- Some of the characters were a bit weak like Hector. To me we're supposed to be sympathetic to him but in all honestly, he's just a bad guy. His purpose in the story is to just drip feed information to the reader and move the plot along which makes him feel like a device and not a believable character. This made the story and Iain lack agency and that we were just waiting until it was decided to move along.

This was still an enjoyable book, but I would beware of the criticisms as it may affect your reading experience. I still think it's worth a go as it has good writing and an engrossing bit of history. Just be prepared for a weaker mystery and some missable characters.

Title: A Wizard’s Guide to Defensive Baking
Author: T. Kingfisher

Title: Twelve Kings in Sharakhai (The Song of the Shattered Sands, #1)
Author: Bradley P. Beaulieu

Title: The 7 1/2 Deaths of Evelyn Hardcastle
Author: Stuart Turton
My Review:
After finishing Devil and the Dark Water (which was a 5 star read for me until the ending), I went in with tempered expectations. The first half was much the same, I was really into the characters, the story, and the world. But in the second half, or at least last ~40%, this took a nose dive for me. I started to find holes in what was going on, plot conveniences, and realized the characters were a lot less interesting than at first glance. The writing is still great, and the author is great at coming up with intriguing ideas. But, the execution has always been mixed for me. I think the perfect way to read this book is to really suspend disbelief. Do not think too deeply about the characters, world, or plot. Just go along for the ride with Aiden.

Quick hits:
+ Intriguing idea for a story. There's a nice little twist that adds some spice in the latter third of the book.
+ Aiden's struggle and coming to terms with each of hosts was fun to read.
- The characters don't have much depth once you start poking around. The Footman for example, starts as a really intriguing character. But in the second half you realize that he has no purpose in the story at all.
- There's a lot of holes in the second half. For example, something happens which is meant to create a sense of tension and feeling of running out of time. But if you remember the rules that were outlined earlier in the book, it completely defeats the tension because you know there's way more time than you're led to believe.
- The ending, similar to Devil and the Dark Water, is just not great. Once again, something somewhat out of character happens, and the book ends. You're left being like "Seriously?". This one is more believable, but I felt like it was a step too far beyond belief.

As you can tell, this one was more mixed than Devil and the Dark Water. Maybe I was more in tune this time around that I noticed more, but I felt the tension and execution was better in Devil and the Dark Water. The story started strong, but eventually it's really easy to pick a lot of holes in the characters and plot. I feel this is true with a lot of time travel stories unless the rules are very strict, which is not actually true here. If you can suspend disbelief easily, I think you'll enjoy this. Otherwise, I think you'll probably also feel pretty mixed. Although the ending isn't good, I would recommend Devil and the Dark Water over this one. 3/5 stars.

Title: The Voyage of the Basilisk (The Memoirs of Lady Trent, #3)
Author: Marie Brennan

Title: The Bone Ships (The Tide Child, #1)
Author: R.J.  Barker
My Review:
Wow. Just wow. This is the perfect example of sometimes just not being in the mood for something, and its worth coming back and trying again. I tried to read this book for the first time in the last 6-8 months, and I was just overwhelmed with the terminology and a bit burnt out. I decided to pick this back up a few weeks ago, and I'm so happy I did. What a ride all around. The character development in this book is top notch. If you take a shot from the first 50 pages, and then another in the last 50 pages, you'll be amazed at how much the characters have changed. The world is unique, with it's own terminology and systems. While it may be overwhelmed at first, eventually you'll put the pieces together, and there's a lot of similarities with our own world from a people perspective. While this is a naval fantasy book, and there's a lot of time spent on a ship, but there's also plenty of action and plot development. If you enjoy great fantasy, with incredible character development, then this is for you. Don't be turned off by it being naval fantasy or that it could be complex, it's worth the journey.

To give you an example of why I think you should read this book: I had a preconceived notion or judgement about alcoholics. One of the characters has this behavior at the start of the book. That really turned me off at the start due to that judgement, and some personal experience. When I came back, I jumped right in from where I ended so I actually forgot about that fact. When I realized it, not only was I invested in everything, but I also came at it from a different perspective (essentially a different version of the character). It made me confront something about myself that I wasn't really aware of. That change not only affected me in real life, but had me even more invested in the growth of this character. I felt connected on a deeper level. That's good character growth!

Quick hits:
+ Character growth is amazing.
+ Meas. What a character. A strong woman without needing to try or be in your face about it. A true leader. She makes everyone better around her by lifting them up.
+ The world is complex but unique.
+ The action is good and keeps you invested. You get the perspective of the untrained and battle hardened which is a nice mix.
+ The naval details and boat journey was engaging throughout.
- The final battle was a bit anticlimactic. It was over pretty fast. It was meant to be a somewhat personal moment for the characters that ended up falling a little flat. Now there was a moment that hints at things for the future, but I was wishing for a bit more.

Due to the final battle, this sits at a 4.5/5 for me, but that's a bit pedantic. A fantastic book through and through. I'm happy I confronted some of my own judgements and came back to this book. This is one I'll be thinking about for a while, and I look forward to continuing the series!

Title: Isla's Reach: The Breaths and Depths (The Breaths and Depths Duology)
Author: Francisca Liliana

Title: Appointment with Death (Hercule Poirot, #19)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
Ah, and we're back. A Christie book always recharges the reading juices. They're easily digestible, fast paced, and have great characters. This was no different in entry number 19. I felt this time Christie wrote one of the most complex set of characters. Mrs. Boyton on the surface is a very mean, cruel, and despicable character. But similar to other Poirot novels, the psychology gets revealed over time and reveals layers to a character who at first seems very one dimensional. This made the whole story engrossing as you learn about all the characters, what makes them tick, and how they fit into the plot. I thoroughly enjoyed this one, and until the very end it looked as if I was going to be right, but as always she pulls the rug out at the very end. I have one complaint which is the resolution. She's done this a couple of times but the resolution is very abrupt and convenient. It's not a major deal but it does suck you out a bit at the end. So this really sits at a 4.5/5 for me rounded up.

Quick hits:
+ Poirot is always great. He shows different sides of himself throughout every story: the father figure, the empath, and the hard nosed detective. His insights are always a treasure to read.
+ The character dynamics felt special in this one. Complex but easy to understand. There's layers to every character revealed throughout the story.
+ Unexpected culprit as always (I really thought I had this one).
- The resolution was abrupt and convenient which takes you out a bit at the end.

If you're this far into Poirot, of course keep going! If you haven't started, what are you waiting for?! Poirot and Christie are great. I'd highly recommend this to fans of mystery, classics, or mysteries.

Title: Saevus Corax Deals with the Dead (Corax Trilogy, #1)
Author: K.J. Parker

Title: The Writing of the Gods: The Race to Decode the Rosetta Stone
Author: Edward Dolnick
My Review:
This book was a very interesting read. I'm honestly landing at a 4 here. There were moments that were very good, with a mix of historical detail and relevant examples. But, then there were others where it felt completely undirected and we ended up on a tangent. For the most part it was very good though. I appreciated learning about the history behind the discovery of the Rosetta stone, as well as the efforts to decode it. It's an area I was completely unfamiliar with, and I certainly learned a lot about language in general. I would warn people though, this book has been described as a thriller, with a race between two minds trying to decode the Rosetta Stone. To be frank, in my opinion, you really won't be getting that. You will be getting a good history of the time period, Egypt, hieroglyphs, decoding the discovery, and on language in general. I would recommend this for fans of Egypt, language, or history.

Quick hits:
+ Overall good overview of the history, time period, discovery, and decoding of the Rosetta Stone.
+ Language theory was really interesting and helps the reader understand the scholastic discussion.
+ Pacing was fast and kept me invested.
+/- Billed as a thriller but in reality is just a non-fiction book about the topic. While timelines are parallel, they don't have much to do with each other and really don't have much to do with the actual result.
- Some random tangents which departed from the story.
- The book never tells you what the actual text on the Rosetta Stone is. It's not the point of the book, but it feels missing.

I was a bit mixed on this one. The writing is good, and when it's focused, the story is incredibly interesting. But there are some departures throughout the story, and missing pieces that brought this down. I would still recommend overall, but just go in with the right expectations.

Title: The Magic Engineer (The Saga of Recluce, #3)
Author: L.E. Modesitt Jr.

Title: The Anvil of Ice (The Winter of the World, #1)
Author: Michael Scott Rohan

Title: Death on the Nile (Hercule Poirot, #18)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
I'm a bit late on this one as I've been busy and didn't have time to sit down and write this. But as expected, it was another great outing with Poirot. What's interesting about this one however, is that we spend a lot of time building to the circumstances of the crime itself. Instead of a murder happening in the first ~50 pages, we spend time with a variety of characters unsure of whether a crime will actually be committed. Poirot trying to prevent a crime he knows will occur at some point was an unexpected change of pace I really appreciated. Of course, this wouldn't be Agatha Christie without a crime so we get there eventually, but you'll appreciate the buildup of the world and characters. What I found the most surprising, was that even though I expected the crime, I was still blown away by the resolution. That's just a testament to how great Christie was, even 18 books into the series. I'm really looking forward to continuing the series, and reaching the 50% mark!

Quick hits:
+ Poirot is the highlight, and we got a new side to him this time.
+ The side characters had depth and were 3 dimensional.
+ While the plot was "expected", I still throughly enjoyed the story and the resolution was fantastic as usual.
+ Christie's writing is so digestable and it's so easy to binge read.

If you've read Poirot before, of course you should read this one! If you haven't read Poirot before, what are you waiting for?! 5/5 easy stars.

Title: Camelot (The Arthurian Tales, #2)
Author: Giles Kristian
My Review:
Wow, wow, wow. This was incredible. I loved all of this. I'm only familiar with the highlights of the Arthurian legend, but this is really approachable regardless, even if you haven't read the first book. I chose to start here because I was in the mood for a character like Galahad. A young man who is burdened by his father's legacy but at his core is just a good man. While Galahad is certainly like he is in the stories (the most chivalrous and honorable knight), he also isn't without flaw. And that is one of Kristian's strengths, every character from the legend feels REAL. A lot of times the Arthurian stories feel stylized, and as a reader you feel distanced from the characters because it's hard to relate to them. But here, all of the characters feel like real people in British history. And that makes the story so much more relatable. There are definitely some valid criticisms to be made of this book (for example, this book focused on 1 overarching quest for a giant portion that felt it never ended), but in the end my love outweighs those criticisms. I loved the story, the characters and the whole journey. You know you've enjoyed something when you can look back at the start and end of the story, and sit back in awe with how far you've come. And let me tell you, the last battle (which was over 40 pages long), my heart didn't stop beating for the entire time. Pure edge of your seat adrenaline.

Quick hits:
+ Relatable story and characters, that feel a real part of history.
+ Well written dialogue and plot.
+ Great action that has you at the edge of your seat.
+ Approachable for fans of Arthurian legend or fans of the first book, without needing to be an expert of either.

I rounded up here, but this sits at a 4.5/5 for me. Everything I wanted from this book, I got. I would highly recommend this to any historical fiction, fantasy or Arthurian legend fan. I'll definitely be checking out the first book, and likely rereading this again in the future!

Title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
Author: Ron Hansen

Title: Loveless, Vol. 1: A Kin of Homecoming
Author: Brian Azzarello

Title: Blood Meridian, or, the Evening Redness in the West
Author: Cormac McCarthy

Title: The Once and Future King (The Once and Future King, #1-4)
Author: T.H. White

Title: The Last Ranger (Ranger of the Titan Wilds, #1)
Author: J.D.L. Rosell

Title: The Seeker (Damian Seeker #1)
Author: S.G. MacLean
My Review:
Settling at a 4 star here. I enjoyed reading this, the historical details were incredibly thorough and as a nerd, I really appreciated the historical world building done by the author. The story was good as was the characters. But I felt the mystery part of the plot kind of just ends at one point in the book and there isn't much fare around it. All the related threads are resolved quickly and cleanly, which left me unsatisfied. The rest of the plot was good and I feel those threads were really the core of what the book is meant to be about, the crime just being the driver to start it all. And that's okay, this is what happens when your expectations don't end up aligning with the reality of the book!

Quick hits:
+ Characters are really varied with interesting backstories. Seeker is obviously the major highlight but there's good nuanced dialogue here between characters with different political views that's done really provocatively.
+ The story has multiple threads, most of which are good.
+ The time period this is set in is really unique and the world building is top notch.
- The mystery resolution is a bit underwhelming.

In the end, this was a really enjoyable read. I would certainly recommend this for historical fiction fans who wants good world building and cool characters. I would just caution this isn't a true mystery book. The crime is a part of the book but not everything. I'll definitely continue with the series.

Title: Dumb Witness (Hercule Poirot, #17)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
A fun and unique return to form, albeit much easier to guess this time around.

I'm not a big fan of short story Poirot. It doesn't have the same fleshed out characters and complex plot that is in the full length novels which I think is Christie's skillset. Unlike Sherlock, Poirot short stories just kind of happen and are very forgettable. While even 17 books in, I can still remember tons of moments from the novels, as they make a much more lasting impression. After Murder in the Mews, I was happy to return to form here and I wasn't disappointed. There's a unique take/twist on the typical mystery here which was a nice change of pace. The characters were interesting, and the plot was deeper than expected. Bob the dog has to be the highlight. Christie's writing for the inner workings of a dog brain was full of dry humor and was such a treat in the story. Unfortunately, guessing the culprit this time around was much simpler than her previous stories. Without about 70 pages left something happens that just puts the answer right in your face. It was fun to feel like I finally guessed one of her endings! But even with another slight twist at the end, it lacked the usual punch at the end that I'm used to. That's okay though because it was still fun and I was enjoy spending time with Poirot.

Quick hits:
+ A different shade of Poirot in this one which had me invested in this different side of him.
+ Side characters felt familiar but had their own twists to make them unique. Bob, Theresa, and Miss Peabody in particular.
+ A different investigation setup than we're used to which was refreshing 17 books in.
- The culprit was fairly obvious with the blatant dangling of the answer in the reader's face. This took away the punch much too early in the story.

Overall, another fun journey with Papa Poirot. While this didn't punch as hard, it was still enjoyable and I'm excited to read the next. Obviously if you've read the first 16 books, of course you're going to read this one. I would recommend some others if you're just looking to jump into Christie or Poirot however.

A couple of other notes: I really appreciated the little nods to previous investigations. It was a nice reward for reading the other stories. And if you've read my other reviews for Poirot, you might be surprised to see no complaints about Hastings! Well he actually wasn't annoying in this one and played much more of the Watson role and that was really great!

Title: The Crown Tower (The Riyria Chronicles, #1)
Author: Michael J. Sullivan
My Review:
This one sat at more like a 3.5 for me. Not because it was bad (I loved Riyria Revelations and Sullivan's writing), this was just a lot more setup and not a lot happening. It took a while before Royce and Hadrian were really introduced to each other, and the side story of setting up Gwen also took a lot of time. I love all these characters, but I think I went into this expecting the similar fare that I'm used to, and we're not quite there yet (operative word being yet). But let me tell you, once things get going, Sullivan is still at his best writing both the characters and the action. You can't stop from continuing to read and just enjoying getting to experience the story. Regardless of this, I love Royce and Hadrian and I can't wait for the next books and their future adventures before we see them again in Revelations.

Quick hits:
+ While of course Royce and Hadrian are not the same as they are in Revelations because it's 12 years younger, but they still feel so similar. If you haven't read them before, you're in for a treat.
+ The story had a nice twist than what you read in the blurb which was cool.
+ The side characters which are important to our main pair and the story feel familiar and I'm looking forward to their further development than what we've already seen.
- There's a ton of setup, which if you've read Revelations, is a jarring change of pace. It feels like reading the first in an entire series instead of really book 7 in release order. If you're just starting here, I think it'll be totally normal for you, but as a long time reader I think you'll feel the same. Because of this there also feels like not much going on. The characters need to get together and the plot is just a way to get there. I think this will improve going forward as well because the adventures will matter.
- The pacing is rather slow. It picks up in the last 50 pages or so, but before that it's a lot of switching perspectives with not much happening (or at least important things happening). I don't think this will be a problem going forward as the characters have kind of come together so to speak but it's present in this book.

Overall, this review sounds really mixed, and maybe it is. But, I love these characters, and this world. I'm really excited where we're going to get to, we just had to get by this initial setup. If you've never read any Sullivan book, you should fix that immediately. And as some others have said, this may be a better starting point for Riyria than Revelations. Either way, jump in, you're messing up!

Title: Murder in the Mews (Hercule Poirot, #16)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
While this was enjoyable (and of course well written), these are mostly forgettable stories (especially the last story). Most of my memories of these stories are actually David Suchet in the adaptations and not the stories themselves. Frankly, I don't think Poirot really shines in short stories like Sherlock does, and Christie's best talents don't reach their full potential either. You'll never walk away feeling cheated or that you didn't have a good time, but compared to the full length novels, you won't walk away feeling floored or that the book made an impression on you. But with a series this long, one can't expect every book to be on the top 10 list :)

Quick hits:
+ Poirot as usual is great. Great to see Japp in one of the stories as well.
+ Short and quick read, typical Christie fair (in a good way).
+ The stories are varied in locale in characters.
- Not enough time to really develop any character or story, making them mostly forgettable unless you've seen the adaptations.
- The last story is essentially pointless. It's like 20 pages with no investigation or anything we're used to. It's just something that happens while Poirot was there and then it ends.

If you're reading Poirot (or have OCD like me), of course you're going to read this! But if you're looking to jump into Poirot and want to start with some short stories, I'd actually recommend skipping and going to a full length novel. They are far superior in my opinion and they're about the same length. On to the next!

Title: The Maltese Falcon
Author: Dashiell Hammett
My Review:
This one was a bit of a mixed bag. There was parts of it that felt like an old Hollywood movie, but there was others that kind of felt all over the place for no reason. This was actually the first classic that I didn't totally vibe with or really felt outdated. I'm not talking the language, but the way the characters acted and what happened in the story. That's to be expected, but there was tons to disagree with here that overwhelmed the experience. Classics always have things you disagree with it, but it usually isn't so blatant to detract from the story. Here it was relatively constant and that took me out of it often.

Quick hits:
+ This reads like a 1900s noir and is really moody like a early 20th century Hollywood movie.
+ The world feels filled out with plenty of characters.
+ The story is intriguing even if it ends up being really simple in the end.
- A lot of sexism and what feels like chauvinism throughout the entire book. Spade treats all of the women in this pretty poorly, even if they aren't the best people.
- The story ends up muddled throughout the second half. What starts as an intriguing setup and a lot of mystery really boils down to something quite simplistic and obvious.

This last bit is personal preference so I'm not docking the book for it, but throughout this Spade is pretty unlikeable. I think that's probably the point, and while there's depth to Spade (he's smarter than he looks), he was not a good guy throughout the whole book. I prefer my detectives to be somewhat redeemable, but again, personal preference.

Overall, there was stuff to like here, but also stuff not too. It wasn't much of a dud (still plenty readable), but didn't end up being 100% my cup of tea. But that's okay. On to the next!

Title: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms (The Tales of Dunk and Egg, #1-3)
Author: George R.R. Martin

Title: Hannibal: Rome's Greatest Enemy
Author: Philip Freeman
My Review:
This was a quick run through Hannibal's history against the Romans and was quite enjoyable. It's hyper focused on Hannibal and really only glosses over the political climate in Carthage and the other Barca siblings who played a big role in Hannibal's success. I'm not a Roman history expert, but it was also refreshing to read a different point of view of the earlier years of the Roman empire and really how the war between Hannibal and the Romans shaped their future. I would recommend this for anyone looking to learn more about one of the greatest generals in history and the only man to ever give a huge fight to Rome.

Quick hits:
+ Fast paced.
+ Focuses on the most important details.
+ Easily digestible regardless of your experience level.
- Lacks depth in some places I think would've rounded out the entire book.
- The epilogue felt wholly unnecessary. There's contradictions abound and the author starts making guesses about hundreds of years in the future beyond Rome and northern Africa. That felt just kind of way out there and not conducive to real discussion and theory.

Overall, a fun non-fiction book. It does what it sets out to do relatively well. I would recommend this for anyone interested in micro-history, one of the great generals or Roman history.

Title: Cards on the Table (Hercule Poirot, #15)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
While still a very good Poirot and Christie book, I walked away with a bit of an underwhelming feeling in my stomach. A lot of people regard this book as their favorite in the series, and I can see why. It has a very intriguing setup that is a change of pace from most mysteries, and while at the start that feels really exciting, by the end it felt much more predictable. I enjoy the surprise and twist of the reveal because it can be so unexpected. Because of all the suspects being murderers, I expected one of them to be the culprit. And because that list was small, it was much easier to guess who the person was. Now, that's not to say this still isn't good, because it definitely is. The characters are done well and the writing is superb as usual. But, I think I have a preference for the typical Christie style and this one missed a little bit for me.

Quick hits:
+ Poirot is still the best.
+ Side characters are great.
+ Intriguing mystery setup.
- Underwhelming conclusion.

Overall, still a good book and still good Poirot. But I'll be glad to get back to the normal style of Poirot again. The adventure continues!

Title: The Wolf of Oren-Yaro (Chronicles of the Bitch Queen, #1)
Author: K.S. Villoso

Title: The Scottish Ladies' Detective Agency (The Scottish Ladies' Detective Agency, #1)
Author: Lydia Travers

Title: Bruno, Chief of Police (Bruno, Chief of Police, #1)
Author: Martin  Walker

Title: Jim Hanvey, Detective (Library of Congress Crime Classics)
Author: Octavus Roy Cohen
My Review:
What an absolute joy ride. I've found that I really love classic mysteries, especially short stories, and this was no different. Hanvey is such a fun and unique character that was incredibly refreshing. The stories were incredibly fun and there was some unique takes on the mysteries as well. Half the time as the reader you had no idea what Hanvey was up to but that made you more invested in the outcome. I've heard Cohen's other works aren't as good and have some blatant racism, but none of that appeared here. Definitely worth checking this out if you're a fan of the golden age of mysteries.

Quick hits:
+ Hanvey is such a unique and interesting character. He's much different than most detectives.
+ The mysteries are mostly unique and they're a bit different than the usual. I was invested in every one and I really was interested in where they were going to go.
+ The characters were unique too. Like the classics the bad guys or thieves weren't necessarily bad. There was respect between Hanvey and the culprit which made for a unique dynamic.

This one was relatively short, with about 8 mysteries. But I thoroughly enjoyed every one. I'm looking forward to checking out more classics and checking out some of the Hanvey novels. I would highly recommend to mystery fans. This one had me laughing, invested in the stories and enjoying the characters.

Title: The Devil and the Dark Water
Author: Stuart Turton
My Review:
Atmospheric, mysterious, with a twist on the classic. But with one of the most mind boggling endings I've read in a long time. This book builds tension and atmosphere really well, making you feel what it would have been like to be trapped on a cursed ship in the middle of the ocean. The story is really interesting, with multiple ongoing mysteries at a time. The characters breath life into the ship and really help shape the world of the novel. For most of this novel, it was sitting at about 4-5 stars and while the initial reveal didn't hit me in an awe defining way, there was a unseen twist that actually made it considerably good. However, within the last 15-20 pages, I felt the author threw all that away for no logical reason I can come up with. It felt contradictory to the characters and to the story, leaving me feeling incredibly unresolved and unsatisfied. Not every book needs to end the way you want it to, but, the ending should still make sense and satisfy the story. I didn't feel that happened here. It felt it threw away all the growth the characters had throughout the story. That hurts more considering how much I enjoyed the rest of the book. It seems this is similar to the author's other works which is unfortunate.

Quick hits:
+ The main characters are really good. They have a mix of personalities, some mirroring each other with slight changes. They add a lot of depth which makes the ship feel really filled out.
+ The story has many parts, and I was invested in where each storyline was going. Some of the reveals were okay, but they still enriched the story.
+ The feeling of the story is done really well. You can feel the tension and the mystery. The melting pot of personalities adds to that.
- The ending is so contradictory to me. It felt like it threw away all of the reveals and character growth that existed in the story.

So why did this end at 3 stars instead of 4 or 5? Well, had this been just a story or a piece of literary fiction, the ending might not have bothered me as much. But a mystery is all about the reveal and ending. You invest in the story to get the experience of that revelation. When the reveal and ending is not good, it feels like the investment isn't worth it. It feels like you wasted your time. And that hurts. But overall this was still written really well and I enjoyed most of it. If you can forgive an arguably bad ending, I would recommend this. There's a lot to like here. Maybe you will even like the ending! I'll still pick up the author's other popular work, but I think I'll go in with lowered expectations for the end.

Title: The Ring that Caesar Wore (Leonidas the Gladiator Mysteries Book 3)
Author: Ashley Gardner
My Review:
I really enjoyed this one. There were some nitpicky things, but overall it read really quickly and definitely felt like the best book in the series so far.

Quick hits:
+ Leonidas and Cassia still continue to thrive, growing individually and together.
+ The story was a little out there for sure, but I actually thought considering that it was handled really well and the resolution was pretty good.
+ The side characters continue to play a large role in the story and it's an interesting dynamic for Leonidas to form relationships as he feels unworthy. I'm really looking forward to where his and Livius' relationship goes.
+ Teases for future adventures that would be a nice change of pace.
- There were a few editing issues littered throughout the book, and I was hoping for a little bit more development between Cassia and Leonidas. It feels like they're at the glass ceiling and the breakthrough moment isn't happening.

The series continues to improve with each installment and this one has certainly been the best. The characters and the world continue to deepen and expand, which is great for those of us reading every book. This can be read as a standalone but it of course works better as an installment. I would recommend the book and series to those who are fans of Ashley's other work or those who are fans of good historical cozy mysteries.

Title: Promise of Blood (Powder Mage, #1)
Author: Brian  McClellan
My Review:
This was a banger. Similar to Kings of the Wyld, this felt like pure heavy metal fantasy. Tons of action, tons of intrigue, and really cool characters. I really took my time with this one, mainly due to being sick and also some personal stuff going on. Every page felt like something was happening in the plot or with the characters, and it hit me in all the right places.

Quick hits:
+ The characters are interesting. Tamas is a man driven by revenge, but also by doing the right thing. And he struggles with that balance throughout the entire book.
+ The action is top notch. It's described well and brings you to the edge of your seat.
+ The world is similar but different. If you go in thinking about the French Revolution, you'll feel a lot of similarities but also a unique fantasy twist.
+ Unexpected twists in the story.
- I was really interested in Adamant's case (I love mysteries). But it just kind of felt rushed to the end with a lot of open questions. I wish that was handled a bit better.
- Some things felt left open for no reason. They were minor things that kept actively getting pushed back from being resolved when it didn't need to be. Looking at you Vlora.

I loved this. It wasn't perfect but it hit me in the best places and really reinvigorated my fantasy love. I'll definitely continue with the series and of course more and more fantasy books. I would highly recommend this to fantasy fans of all kinds.

Title: Murder at the Seven Dials (Bow Street Duchess Mystery #1)
Author: Cara Devlin
My Review:
This was a fun little historical mystery that I had some issues with but overall was solid. I enjoyed the characters and while the resolution didn't blow my mind, it was still a good mystery.

Quick hits:
+ Main characters are good, each with their own motives and reasonable actions.
+ Hugh is a bit different of a main character and I appreciated his unique background which is somewhat mysterious.
+ The mystery feels fast paced and the timeline of the Duke's sentencing adds pressure to the pot.
+ Hugh and Audrey have great chemistry.
- Once one of the character details is revealed, the mystery became quite obvious to me considering the other bits of the story.
- Audrey falls into the trap of a lot of historical intrepid heroines in that she is supposed to be smart but yet is so impulsive that she puts herself into stupidly dangerous situations for no other reason than to prove a point, requiring the main partner to save them. It feels really contrived to me. I'm all about intelligent heroines, but it's increasingly frustrating when she makes decisions for no logical reason.

This was a fun experience. While I had issues which frustrated me, the characters, their chemistry and the mystery were good enough to give it a go. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a fun, cozy, historical mystery to read. I'll be picking up the next book in the series.

Title: The Rise and Fall of Ancient Egypt
Author: Toby Wilkinson

Title: The Ottoman Empire: The Classical Age 1300-1600
Author: Halil İnalcık

Title: The Forgetting Moon (The Five Warrior Angels, #1)
Author: Brian Lee Durfee

Title: A World Beneath the Sands: The Golden Age of Egyptology
Author: Toby Wilkinson

Title: The Code Book: The Science of Secrecy from Ancient Egypt to Quantum Cryptography
Author: Simon Singh

Title: The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire
Author: Edward Gibbon
Additional Authors: Daniel J. Boorstin, Giovanni Battista Piranesi, Hans-Friedrich Mueller

Title: A Prelude to Ashes (The Ashes of Avarin, #0.5)
Author: Thiago Abdalla

Title: A Murder of Mages (The Maradaine Constabulary, #1)
Author: Marshall Ryan Maresca

Title: Average Jones
Author: Samuel Hopkins Adams
My Review:
These Golden Age short story mysteries are just my jam. This one was different that the others in that these are more fun romps than they are guess "who done it" but I thoroughly enjoyed each one. Average is such an intriguing character who's dry humor still brings a smile to my face almost 100 years later. The side characters bring depth to the stories and the world as well. I really wish there were more stories and/or a full novel with Average as the main characters, but, I'm happy I got these stories regardless.

Quick hits:
+ Average is a fun character. His wit, his intelligence and his non pompous lifestyle make for an enjoyable main character. I wish we got to explore more of him.
+ The side characters fill out the world in the individual stories as well as the wider plotline.
+ I really felt like I was in the time period with the characters.
+ A unique twist on the detective story using advertisements and creating characters who were similar to the Golden Age detective and Sherlock, but unique enough they didn't feel derivative.

So why only 4 stars? While I had a bunch of fun with this one, none of the stories are distinctly memorable since I wasn't surprised at the resolutions (or didn't have the association of trying to guess the culprit like a traditional novel). I would highly recommend this to mystery fans, it's very quick and fun which is a good palette cleanser for your hard hitting mysteries! 4/5.

Title: The Scarecrow Killer (Detective Cassie Rowan #2)
Author: Margaret Murphy
My Review:
First, thanks to Netgalley for a copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

This one took me longer than usual to get through, but it wasn't because of the book, I just had some personal things going on that kept me from reading. This was mostly good. The book is written well, the main characters are well realized (and will feel familiar if you've read or watched modern police procedurals). I had some gripes with some side characters and the resolution but this was solid regardless. An important note: I have not read the first book but I didn't feel lost at all. There's references to the first book, but nothing that makes you feel left out so you can definitely read as a standalone.

Quick hits:
+ Cassie is an intriguing character. She's at a point of her career where she's built the skills to be a good detective, but she's still learning some of the finer details which will make her come into her own. She never feels petulant or annoying (even with her short temper), she feels like a real modern member of the police.
+ The premise of the book is really interesting and I had fun seeing the investigation progress.
+ Most of the side characters were good. They each had a part to play in the story and even put Cassie in a bit of a mentor role. Warman and Jackie are the highlights.
- Jim North was beyond annoying, and it felt there were moments he was shoehorned in just to be annoying. I get why he is the way he is, but by the 75% mark I was already beyond annoyed.
- The resolution just kind of happens out of nowhere. It isn't that you couldn't see how it happened, but it just pops up in a chapter and you get the explanation later. It felt forced and not like a natural progression of the story.
- The story felt a bit long. The number of pages were fine, but once I was at around ~80%, I was expecting to hit the point of the fast paced wrap up of the story that is common in most mysteries, but I did not. It still felt like the story was in the middle and then we were just at the end and not that the evidence drove the conclusion.

As you can see, I'm a bit mixed. This is a solid mystery read, but I don't think it'll blow your socks off. There's enough good here to recommend to mystery fans, and of course readers of the series. But for me this sits at about 3/5.

Title: Murder as a Fine Art (Thomas De Quincey, #1)
Author: David Morrell

Title: Murder in Mesopotamia (Hercule Poirot, #14)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
At this point I'm running out of unique or original things to say about Christie's books. She's an incredibly consistent writer, and there's always something new to enjoy in each book. I have gripes of course, but it's clear it's just the style of how she wanted to tell the story. If I can look past that, which to be fair aren't that annoying, the meal and dessert that are these books are just plain awesome. If you haven't read a Christie book, or more specifically Poirot, do yourself a favor and change that. Part of what makes classic mysteries so special is that they're just pure fun. They can certainly deal with heavy topics, and obviously include murder, but they put a focus on comic relief and have characters that are special and a joy to be around. This book has all of these, and so does all the other Poirot books. So read em!

Quick hits:
+ Poirot is still a joy. He never gets old.
+ Nurse Leatheran is a fun character to be around. She's a serious character, and provides some dry comic relief throughout the story. But she's also a great sidekick.
+ An expected yet unexpected reveal. I can't say more for spoilers, but while I figured it out, I didn't! A good trick in this one to me.
+ A mysterious cast of characters. Classic Christie style where multiple people have a legitimate motive and I was eager to learn all their backstories.
- Classic Christie doing a lot of setup before the real mystery begins. It's not poorly written or boring, but waiting a hundred pages for Poirot to show up in the story gets old really quick.

Simply, another great hit. If you read all my reviews for the series you'll know this is pretty standard. Agatha Christie and I just have a connection. She understands just what I like and always delivers. I look forward to the next adventure! 5/5.

Title: We Ride the Storm (The Reborn Empire, #1)
Author: Devin Madson

Title: Deadly Secrets (Angus Brodie & Mikaela Forsythe #2)
Author: Carla Simpson
My Review:
Another pretty good excursion with Brodie and Forsythe. Most of my problems from the first book are still prevalent here, but I think if you approach this book as pure popcorn flick style, you'll look past most things and just enjoy the story. Even with my problems, it's got a good enough story and characters that you can enjoy the experience.

Quick hits:
+ Brodie and Forsythe have great chemistry and it's fun to read their interactions.
+ All the characters have a role in the story and don't feel like filler.
+ Forsythe is independent without being stupid and putting herself in ridiculous situations.
- The writing is pretty inconsistent. There are moments where it feels like a chapter was a part of two different writing sessions. You'll read a paragraph where Mikaela says something, and then regurgitates the same thought or explanation 2 paragraphs later just in a slightly different way.
- Brodie is inconsistently Scottish again. It's better than book 1, but still noticeable. Maybe it's only supposed to be when he's angry?
- The culprit is fairly obvious considering the confines of the story and available suspects. The resolution was really rushed in explaining the reasoning in the last chapter which was slightly annoying.
- We spend so much time talking about Brodie's mysterious backstory with barely any dog fooding of hints or information that it starts to make me care much less about what it actually is. It's hinted at so many times in this story with no push towards revelation that it feels like the reveal is going to be disappointing and something really as simple as one case that he disagreed with and walked away.

So why 3 stars? Because again, if you approach this as a purely cozy and popcorn flick style, it's enjoyable enough to have some fun. But I wouldn't go into this expecting to be blown away. I had plenty to complain about here while reading, but I still read the whole thing and enjoyed it overall. If you read book 1, it's more of the same and if you're looking for a quick and easy cozy, I'd recommend this to you. I'll likely keep picking up the books in the series as I need a palette cleanser.

Title: The Scarlet Pimpernel
Author: Emmuska Orczy
My Review:
What can I say about this book? It's frankly one of my favorite stories ever. It has everything you could want: good villain, intriguing main characters, a romp of a story, action and of course some romance too. It obviously has some dated dialogue and sentiments, but it's just fun from start to finish. To me, this is what a classic is, a story you can enjoy and feel regardless of when it released, and it still hits you the same way.

Quick hits:
+ Percy is such a great character. He's dynamic and mysterious, keeping the reader on their toes, never knowing what he'll say or do next.
+ Chauvelin is a great villain. The tense moments created with him in the room have you on the edge of your seat.
+ The side characters have a nice role in the story and it's fun watching them simp over The Scarlet Pimpernel.
+ Percy and Marguerite have such good chemistry. Every scene between them you can feel the tension and emotion between them. Their story is such a great subplot. The scene after the party when they're outside is just *chef's kiss*.
- A bunch of antisemitic remarks in the story. Unfortunately a standard of the time. There's one section of the story that contains a lot, but the rest doesn't have anything really.

Overall, I love this book. I love the writing, story, and characters. The story feels really personable even for being 100 years old, and I would highly recommend people read this, especially if you appreciate classics. Also, if you haven't, I highly recommend watching the movie with Leslie Howard and Merle Oberon. It's not a direct adaptation, but it keeps so much of the core and heart of the story. I prefer it much more than the one from the 80s or 90s, and it evokes the same feeling the book did for me. I look forward to my next reread!

Title: Trouble in Nuala (The Inspector de Silva Mysteries #1)
Author: Harriet Steel

Title: The Birth of Blue Satan (Blue Satan And Mrs. Kean, #1)
Author: Patricia Wynn

Title: For Deader or Worse: Another John Pickett Mystery (John Pickett Mysteries Book 6)
Author: Sheri Cobb South

Title: The Silent Bullet: A Classic Crime Fiction Short-Story Collection (Library of Congress Crime Classics)
Author: Arthur B. Reeve
My Review:
This one was a lot of fun, and if you've read my Sherlock reviews, you'll know I love short story mysteries! The last short story in this one brought the rating down a little bit for me. It was by no means bad, but the middle had so much mathematical theory that distracted from the mystery that it wasn't as enjoyable as the rest. One thing I want to definitely point out is, to me, the "American Sherlock" comparisons are a bit unfair to the author and the character. Saying Craig Kennedy is a Sherlock rip off is like saying someone who can throw a football is Tom Brady. My point is, sure are there similarities? Absolutely. But they're entirely different personalities, with different approaches to problems and solutions. I will say the format is very similar for how the short story is told, but every story has a beginning, middle and end. So don't go into this thinking this is American Sherlock. Go in expecting a fun set of stories with two likable main characters!

Quick hits:
+ Craig and Walter have great chemistry and are fun characters to be around. They're very personable and how they approach cases is fresh.
+ Very varied cases with topical stories of the time (Typhoid Mary, The Black Hand).
+ The middle sections of the short stories are the best as you learn about inventions of the time and how he uses science to solve the case.
- 1 or 2 instances of racist language. Not excusable but this was from the early 1900s and the Library of Congress Crime Classics edition keeps it in.
- Last story was more meh.

Overall, a very enjoyable experience. The late 19th and early 20th century authors really know how to write great short story mysteries. It's something I wish there was more of today. I would highly recommend if you like classic mysteries and want some stories that were very topical for the time! 4/5 stars. I'll definitely check out the novels. Now I'm off to find more short stories!

Title: The A.B.C. Murders (Hercule Poirot, #13)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
I'm not going to lie to you, this has always been one of my favorite Poirot stories. Unlike The Big Four which felt like a departure from the normal style, this takes a story that seems much less grounded than usual, and turns it into a very personal story. It has everything you could want (or sometimes not if you're like me): Hastings, Papa Poirot, Japp, twists and turns, and good character work. But even with things that I normally wouldn't appreciate, the story is so good here that it overrides those negatives. If you haven't been spoiled, skip the adaptations and read this book. You'll be pleasantly surprised at the twist on a serial killer story. Maybe the reveal isn't as impactful today because these types of stories have been told so many times, but you'll appreciate how unique this was at the time (and hopefully surprised as well).

Quick hits:
+ Poirot at the top of his game.
+ Good side characters.
+ Unique story with a nice twist.
+ Tense story and pacing, making you anticipate the shoe drop.
+ Perspective changes which was a nice change of pace.

Overall, this was another banger. I anticipated I would love this since I've always loved the story, and I was glad to be right. I can't wait to get to the next story, and I highly recommend for mystery fans, Poirot fans and readers in general!

Title: Murder at the Carnival (Miss Hayward & the Detective Series #1)
Author: Helen Goltz

Title: The Master of Mysteries
Author: Gelett Burgess
My Review:
I'm starting to realize I really appreciate a good short story mystery. These days, most mysteries are written as full length novels. There's nothing wrong with that, but there's just something about a short story that's so awesome. Being able to create interesting characters, mystery and resolution all in 30 pages or less must be quite a challenge. Astro and Valeska are such fun characters and while not all the mysteries are amazing, they're all really fun and there are some great ones in there.

Quick hits:
+ Astro is such an intriguing character. He feels like a more modern and social Holmes. He has great wit and is very intelligent.
+ Astro's relationship with Valeska was so refreshing. Sure, there was some romance there. BUT, Astro never puts Valeska down. He's constantly trying to train and challenge her so that she could be the best version of herself. He also actively relies on her during investigations and for his "day job".
+ Mysteries are mixed in style, hitting all the notes for mystery fans. Murders, robberies, missing persons, etc.
- Some racist language (unfortunately to be expected in stories that are 100 years old). I can only remember a couple of times in all 462 pages.
- Not as many memorable short stories. Enjoyable while you read them, but not as memorable as Sherlock for example (i.e. The Speckled Band, The Redheaded League, etc.).

Overall, I would highly recommend this for anyone who is a mystery fan or classic mystery fan. There's plenty to love here and there's also some refreshing takes in here. Now I'm off to find more short story mysteries to read!

Title: Death in the Clouds (Hercule Poirot, #12)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
Man, Agatha really loves writing these love stories. Not to say they aren't realistic but they always feel so shallow. I get Papa Poirot likes to be a matchmaker but sheesh it's every book! However, the rest of the book was great. Usually when Hastings isn't around, the beginning of the book is always so slow setting up the POV characters and story. But not this time, Poirot was involved from the start in an intriguing mystery filled with fun side characters like Japp and Fournier taking a bigger role. The resolution was good, the book moved quickly, there was multiple storylines and was enjoyable from start to finish.

Quick hits:
+ Poirot is always true to himself. Great character.
+ More Japp and Fournier.
+ Intriguing mystery setup with a good resolution (not necessarily blow your socks off but still really solid).
+ Multiple lines of inquiry which kept things interesting and engaging.
- Love stories are so blah. They're always surface level and tend to be very unbelievable (not because they couldn't be, they just aren't actually flushed out).

Overall, another fun journey. We're on pace to potentially finish the entire series this year or early 2024, time to keep grinding!

Title: Blood Debts (Leonidas the Gladiator Mysteries, #1.5)
Author: Ashley Gardner
My Review:
I tend to forget to read novellas in the series I’m reading, especially mystery since they don’t typically have the same plot development as say fantasy novellas. I decided this one would be a good way to wrap up 2022 and finish my reading challenge. I enjoyed this one, there was only 1 thing that bothered me but that’s it. This book takes place between books 1 and 2 so I read this out of order and had to remember that this takes place before events in book 2, but that’s on me! Honestly this can be read as a stand-alone if you’re interested in giving this series a shot but don’t want to get into a full novel. Definitely recommend the series if you’re into mysteries and Ancient Rome.

Quick hits:
+ Leonidas and Cassia have good development in this.
+ Side characters are solid, and show the true character of the characters.
+ An enjoyable mystery, fairly obvious but that’s okay since it’s a novella with limited cast.
+ Good morally ambiguous ending.
- One of the resolutions is a bit far fetched to me. Being deliberately vague here for spoilers but there’s an assumption that something goes away that honestly feels a bit unlikely.

Overall, a good and quick read to wrap up the year. If you want to give the series a shot, this is a good place to start and I would recommend for those reading the series. It sits well between books 1 and 2. Now we patiently wait for book 3.

Title: Children of Ash and Elm: A History of the Vikings
Author: Neil Price

Title: What Child is This? (Sherlock Holmes Adventure #5)
Author: Bonnie MacBird
My Review:
This was a one sitting read for me, absolutely flew through it. It had everything I like in a Sherlock story: interesting characters who aren’t just black and white, a morally ambiguous decision Sherlock needs to make, a fun mystery and an emotionally hitting story. Bonnie is just the author for me. The way she writes her stories and characters resonate with me so well. And once again, she created an awesome ride full of everything that was a pleasure to read around the holidays.

Quick hits:
+ Sherlock and Watson are great per usual. Their friendship and banter were at an all time high.
+ Emotionally impactful story. Similar to Unquiet Spirits, this was a very grounded and human story about real people experiencing real issues. This felt like something that actually took place or could have taken place. I felt the emotional punch at the end.
+ Well drawn and realistic characters. They’re all flawed and human, making Sherlock’s decisions more impactful.
+ Heffie, Heffie and more Heffie. She’s just so much fun.
+ Fast paced and original. Great resolution to the mystery.

Overall, another banger from Bonnie. Highly recommend for Sherlock fans as well as mystery fans. Unfortunately for me, I’m caught up now and have to wait like the rest of you. But I look forward to the next adventure!

Title: The Ides of April (Flavia Albia Mystery, #1)
Author: Lindsey Davis

Title: Three Act Tragedy (Hercule Poirot, #11)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
I struggled with this, but it taught me a few things about Christie. This really sits at a 3.5/5 for me. There were awesome parts but a lot of just eh.

Quick hits:
+ Poirot is great as usual.
+ Interesting characters and story. Mr. Satterthwaite took time to grow on me but what an intriguing narrator. Similar to Poirot but different. I would be happy to read more stories with him, especially with that past…
+ The reveal was unexpected and great. I really thought it was someone else. And the way the story was told as if a real play!
- For as much as Hastings gets on my nerves, when he’s not there, the stories are much slower and Poirot shows up much later. I don’t want to read 150 pages before Poirot is a main character.
- Christie loves to write a little bit of relationship drama or love stories in her books. But in my opinion, they’re never actually believable. Usually they’re smaller parts but this time it was a major part of the whole book and it was just blah. Especially the resolution.

There was a bunch to love here, good characters and an intriguing and complex mystery. But there was some long going annoyances that brought this down for me. Still overall enjoyed and will keep reading the series. Onto the next adventure!

Title: Sherlock Holmes: The Complete Novels and Stories, Volume Two (Sherlock Holmes #6-9)
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
My Review:
1,796 pages later, the journey is complete. I'm sad that it's over, but I'm so happy I took the ride. There's no need for me to regurgitate how important Sherlock Holmes is. But these stories are personal to me as I'm a major mystery lover. I love trying to solve the problem along with the detective. In fact, I actually really see some of myself in Holmes. Like Sherlock, I also need constant brain stimulation. I also need to solve problems, and it enjoy it for the game's sake and not for any recognition (nowhere near as talented clearly). Now, unlike Sherlock, I don't have some of the same faults with drugs for example. All of this to say this entire journey felt really special to me. It's clearly a classic and I would recommend readers give it a shot, especially the short stories. But, beyond that, if you're someone like me, or someone that feels disconnected from others and the world, give Sherlock a chance. You may find yourself connecting with him, Watson, and finding that even if you feel alone, there's a place for you in this world.

Quick hits:
+ Sherlock and Watson. Plain and simple, they are just the best and have great chemistry. Watson's self awareness and knowledge of his role in their working relationship is vastly better than Poirot and Hastings for example. Also, the increased depth of personal relations between the two was awesome.
+ The variety of stories. Some stories coming from Sherlock's perspective, some resulting in Sherlock deciding what he believes justice should be, and all around good crime variety.
+ A continued variety of characters in the stories with different roles, including police other than Lestrade.
+/- My only real complaint is that the collection just sort of ends. There's no clear final story where it's "the final case". But maybe that's okay. Maybe it lets us know Watson had some untold stories left, or that Sherlock continued to solve minor problems in his retirement. But in my heart I know I would've appreciated a "fin" moment of closure.

There's not much else to say, it's Sherlock and if you're a mystery fan you should try it. There's tons of great short stories, and the novels are fun (although be prepared for perspective changes before the solution is revealed). Even if you're not, I'd recommend it. Doyle created memorable characters, and you may find yourself connecting to them regardless. I know I certainly did! 5/5, highly recommend and I look forward to rereading again in the future.

Title: The Corpse at Ravenholm Castle (A Lady Thea Mystery #2)
Author: Jessica    Baker
My Review:
A nice and breezy read, perfect for this time of the year. As I'm sure is common with everyone, this time of the year gets quite busy with the holidays and travel so dedicated reading time is harder to find. These types of books are perfect because they aren't too deep but are still fun and quick reads. I read the first book a while ago but I didn't feel lost here, so it's easy to pick up. You could read it as a standalone and not really be lost.

Quick hits:
+ Characters are fun and enjoyable. Sometimes they stretch a little beyond belief where they have the perfect backstory or skillset for a specific situation, but they don't break the flow of the book.
+ Fast paced with easily digestible prose.
+/- The mystery is fairly obvious. The cast of suspects isn't that large and it's easy to put the pieces together. However, this is a cosy so it isn't trying to stump the reader.
- My only real "criticism" is it's not clear to me why Thea and Leslie aren't just together. There's no clear obstacles but this is really minor.

Overall, this was an enjoyable cosy read. It won't blow your socks off, but it'll keep you entertained throughout the ride. I'll definitely keep picking up books in this series.

Author: Michael Michel

Title: Murder in Postscript (A Lady of Letters Mystery)
Author: Mary  Winters

Title: Dark of Night (Dr. Evan Wilding #2)
Author: Barbara Nickless
My Review:
Another fun ride with Evan and Addie. I did have some minor gripes with this one (not really anything to do with the story itself) but it was still a great experience overall.

Quick hits:
+ Evan is still such a fun main character. Incredibly smart, but also flawed, making him a very believable character.
+ Evan's collaboration with others is always a treat.
+ Evan's introspection and growth in this book. This story is personal to him, and gets him to reflect on himself, his role at the university, and his future.
+ The crime was much more nuanced around this time. I have no problems reading about serial killers like book 1, but I appreciate mixed criminology in a series, and this one definitely took some unexpected twists that made this a different mystery than the first.
- I would have liked more Addie and Patrick in this one. Unlike book 1 where their collaboration was very intertwined, this feels much more like Evan's story that happens to involve the police instead of the other way around. This wasn't bad, but it felt much more like all of the plot revolved around this with the occasional appearance with some information for Evan.
- The resolution between characters felt a little forced and awkward to me. I'm being deliberately vague here to avoid spoilers. I didn't mind where the relationships ended up, but it really didn't feel natural to me from where we started to where we ended. Especially considering how just out of the blue and fast everything was.

I enjoyed this ride once again just like book 1, although I'd say on my initial read of this I enjoyed it a little less than book 1. I had more noticeable gripes in this one compared that made this more of a mixed bag trending towards great. I'll definitely continue in the series, and I think my gripes will not be repeated in the next adventure.

Title: Sherlock Holmes: The Complete Novels and Stories, Volume I (Vintage Classics)
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
My Review:
A collection like this is hard to review considering how large it is, as well as the mix of novels and short stories. Going into this, I was worried I wouldn't like this much as much as I've enjoyed the Sherlock adaptations and pastiches I've read already. But this was so awesome! It still holds up today, and really set the standard for what detective fiction could be: interesting characters, an intriguing mystery with unexpected resolutions. The second set of short stories were amazing, and I think better than the first set. This makes some sense since they came out later where Doyle had more experience. The novels were classic, and the Hound of the Baskervilles told it's story in an unexpected way which was really interesting. Highly recommend for any fellow Sherlockian or someone looking to try classic detective fiction.

Quick hits:
+ Sherlock and Watson at their best. Watson is such a great side character who although is meant to be the reader's gateway, stands on his own (see Hound of the Baskervilles). He's a much better side character than Hastings from Poirot.
+ The stories are varied and explore many different themes.
+ The mysteries were complex and didn't always go the expected way.
+ The volume was structured well by breaking up the novels with short stories.

I highly recommend this. I'm glad it wasn't a let down, and I've already started volume 2 with more stories I've never experienced before. I'm really looking forward to the experience!

Title: A Tale of Two Murders (A Dickens of a Crime, #1)
Author: Heather Redmond

Title: Lord Edgware Dies (Hercule Poirot, #9)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
Another Poirot adventure in the books, and it was mostly good. This was really a 4.5 star for me, but you know GoodReads, can only have whole numbers! I have some gripes in this one but it didn't ruin the core mystery for me, and it definitely ended in an unexpected way.

Quick hits:
+ Poirot is always good, he's true to himself and it's always fun to watch him work out a problem.
+ The mystery was great, and mostly unexpected. At the reveal at the end, all my theories came crumbling down in front of me. I really thought it was going one of two ways and even believed I was right towards the end, but nope! She hoodwinked me again.
+ Christie's writing is great and her characters are always compelling. No matter the book length, they're quick reads.
+ Some very unique characters in this one. Christie's characters are always good, but a couple in this were really of a different style which was refreshing.
- I really am starting to dislike Hastings. There are moments where he's okay but he gets on my nerves more often than not now. He continually follows the same formula which is predictable and serves no other purpose than that. At least for Watson, he has a role in the medical side and for the most part supports Holmes. Hastings will go from one page thinking Poirot is a genius to the next thinking he's too old. What a flaky "friend".

A warning for those reading the books, there is some antisemitism in this book just like the last one unfortunately. I get a different time and all that but it felt truly unnecessary even in the story.

Overall, this was another great read with another great mystery. Christie continues to write compelling books and I look forward to the next adventure (hopefully with less Hastings)!
