Title: The Three Locks (Sherlock Holmes Adventure #4)
Author: Bonnie MacBird
My Review:
One of the joys of reading is finding an author that you just click with. Their style, their characters and their storytelling all hit you in the right way. Bonnie MacBird is one of those authors for me. This is the 4th book in a row I've read by her that was just fantastic. I'm sad that I only have 1 more book to go before I'm caught up and have to wait for the next installment just like everyone else. This book was fun from start to finish and for the last ~130 pages, I literally could not put the book down. It was fast paced, with tons of reveals and turns. I only guessed one thing and it ended up not even being that important! Any words I write won't do this book justice. The characters were great, the story was compelling and sad, and there was plenty of growth which is surprising for a world and characters you know so well. Read this series!

Quick hits:
+ Sherlock and Watson continue to be great, with more growth than you'd expect.
+ Christie like side characters that were extremely compelling and really enhanced the story. Added a certain realistic sadness as well.
+ Multiple mysteries which keeps you on your toes and creates tons of pace.
+ The last ~130 pages are GREAT.

I would recommend this book to any mystery fan. Whether you've read the previous books or not (or Sherlock fiction in general), you can pick this up and you SHOULD. I love this book, one of the most enjoyable I've read this year. I can't wait to read book 5. Thank you Bonnie!

Title: The Throne of Ice and Ash (The Runewar Saga #1)
Author: J.D.L. Rosell

Title: Peril at End House (Hercule Poirot, #8)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
This is one of my favorite Poirot stories. I love the resolution and I love the path to get there. I can remember my surprise at the ending when David Suchet revealed the killer. Unfortunately, there was a few things in the book that made this less than a 5 star for me.

Quick hits:
+ Poirot really has to work for this one, and it's fun watching him have to work hard to figure it out.
+ The story is so good in this one. The reveal is unexpected, and even the reveal has reveals.
+ Christie's character work is top notch as usual. The characters are all twined together and they each have motives.
+ Having the gang back together is always nice.
+/- I already knew the story so while it was enjoyable, it didn't pack the same punch.
- There's always usually some digs at Hastings, but this time felt like overkill. There's non stop digs at Hastings and it got very annoying.
- This book definitely shows it's age, a bit of antisemitism in this one.

Overall, it was fun to get to re-experience this story. It certainly had some bits I did not like, but otherwise, it's full of everything you'd like in a Poirot story. I'm looking forward to the next adventure.

Title: The Devil’s Due (Sherlock Holmes Adventure #3)
Author: Bonnie MacBird
My Review:
Bonnie and I just get each other. Each of her books are not only high quality, but FUN. While there's tons of darker themes, there's always that undercurrent of "the game's afoot Watson!". This was another great entry in the series.

Quick hits:
+ Sherlock and Watson as usual. Sherlock definitely went through the ringer in this one.
+ The story was incredibly complex with tons of moving pieces.
+ Mycroft is always a delight.
- I didn't feel I could truly figure out the culprit as this one was deep mystery.

I really enjoyed this one. I can't wait to get into the next one!

Title: A Deadly Affair (Angus Brodie & Mikaela Forsythe #1)
Author: Carla Simpson
My Review:
This was mostly good and the mystery was relatively solid but with some wholes in my opinion.

Quick hits:
+ The characters were enjoyable and the story was mostly good.
+/- The story wasn't truly a mystery. To me, a mystery is something that the reader can solve along with the characters. This was more a thriller where the plot unfolds to the reader, and not with much information.
- Having finished the book, it literally makes no sense why the driving plot point (at least for Mikaela) even happens. To me it doesn't really fit with the villain's motives, like at all.
- Angus feels Scottish only half the time. There's tons of time where his dialogue seems really educated English and not Scottish at all.

Overall, there was quality here and I would recommend for someone looking for a mysterious piece of historical fiction. I'd definitely be interested in checking out book two. There was some nagging things here for me that prevented higher than a 3 star, but that's okay, not every book is perfect.

Title: Death Behind Silent Walls (The Victoria Sedgewick Mysteries, #1)
Author: Blythe Baker
My Review:
This book wasn't really as bad as the score I gave it, it's more my experience with it. I've read multiple other Baker books and enjoyed them, this one just had some things that really bugged me.

Quick hits:
+ The characters were good, and I appreciated how they didn't need to break out of their roles in society for the story. They investigated within their roles, and that's so refreshing.
+ Fast paced, quick read.
- The notion that servants would all willingly take less pay for their position (at least half) is quite silly, especially considering the clear description of lack of funds by the mistress.
- I hate investigating off screen. It makes for a mundane mystery and honestly for not an enjoyable experience.
- It was blatantly obvious what the mystery really was and who the culprit was from pretty much the introduction. I have no problem guessing the culprit before the reveal, but not that early in the story.

I think this will improve in further books, and I'm willing to give it another chance. Just a little too much that hurt my own experience.

My Review:
A fun and unique historical mystery that was mostly enjoyable. Most historical mysteries set during the 1800s are set in England. I really appreciate a new location with it's own society structure and piece of history. Of course there are similarities, but they're things common of the time and not the place. The characters are fun and this definitely falls more on the cozy side, but I would definitely recommend if you're looking for something fun and relatively short.

Quick hits:
+ The characters are fun and engaging. It makes it feel like a filled out world.
+ The setting is unique and comes with it own's interesting pieces (for example what those of Chinese descent experienced in this time period).
+ The story is mostly engaging, there are definitely conveniences but it didn't detract from my enjoyment much.
+ The pace is relatively fast, not much bumbling around.
- The mystery ended up being relatively simple and quite obvious when you really think about it.
- Parts of the story felt almost like it was going in one direction and then didn't. Maybe they were meant to be red herrings but it almost felt more jarring. It's possible this was me though (I've been reading a bunch of Christie and Sherlock).

Overall, this was fun and I enjoyed my time with it. I really think this is 3.25-3.5/5 stars but would recommend for someone looking for a quick and enjoyable read. I'll be continuing with the series for sure.

Another great book by Christie! This one took getting used to as it has a different narration style than the previous 4 books, but once it got going it was very enjoyable.

Quick hits:
- The beginning felt very slow. A lot of setup since the narration wasn't done by Hastings. Poirot not showing up until like page 80 made me sad.

It seems I was mixed but I still really enjoyed this once the story got going. I will continue my Poirot read soon!

My Review:
Another awesome time spent with Sherlock and Watson. I had a couple of gripes towards the end that lowered this to 4 stars for me, but overall, it's another awesome adventure. Sherlock and Watson feel very much like you know them, but with slightly more depth that a modern voice provides unlike the original writing.

Quick hits:
- Sherlock and Watson are true to themselves.
- The side characters felt pretty fleshed out and in a Christie way, all had their own realistic motives.
- The story is complex with a lot of moving pieces and feels Sherlockian.
- The pace fell to a crawl in the last 20ish% for an information dump that felt like it could've been handled better. The info being sprinkled out more consistently would've been better. The pace before was moving very quick and then instantly crashed.
- The reveal felt pretty obvious to me.

I thoroughly enjoyed this, although with some issues towards the end. I'll definitely be continuing!

My Review:
Another enjoyable trek through 20th Century England. I had some dislikes in this one, but nothing that killed my enjoyment. We finally have some progression for the characters, but it'll be interesting to see how it plays out in the future books.

Quick hits:
+ I appreciated more of Harry's father and Uncle in this, both fun characters.
+ Side characters are more engaged in this one. Flossy and Johnathon were annoying in this one. But Cleo's aunt was more involved which was a nice change of pace.
+ Progression for some of the side characters, although not really sure what role they'll all have in the future stories.
- If I have to hear Cleo say her friendship with Harry is broken one more time after every single disagreement or argument I'm going to lose my mind. It's as if she's never interacted with people before.
- The mystery resolves in like the last chapter and the reader isn't given enough information to really solve it. Not a big deal, but a lot of brand new info and jumping in the last 40 pages.
+/- I really like the progression for Harry and Cleo, they're becoming more like partners and obviously there's something there. But there's a huge obstacle Cleo just isn't acknowledging or confronting and I'd like to see that resolved soon as we're about to be in book 5. But we'll see.

Overall, another enjoyable and fast read. I'll be continuing in the series and having read a bunch of the author's previous works, I know the quality will stay consistent.

Author: C.J. Archer
My Review:
For some reason, I stopped after the previous books and decided it was time to continue. I enjoy reading these fast paced and light mysteries. Harry and Cleo have good chemistry and exploring the turn of the 20th century is interesting.

Quick hits:
+ The mysteries are solid, nothing to blow your socks off but enjoyable.
+ The characters are well written and I appreciate the little Mayfair world (if only we got more Mr. Hobart).
+ I like the flip on the trope where Cleo isn't just some poor relation, her family cares about her.
- Cleo can sometimes be a little frustrating. I appreciate her independence, but Harry is being a gentleman and she doesn't always recognize his perspective. I know she's managing her uncle, but there could be real consequences and she doesn't always see that.
- Some characters have no purpose, like Johnathon, not sure why they're there.

Overall, these are fun, breezy mysteries. I would highly recommend as a palette cleanser or a good time.

Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
Another adventure with Poirot, and this one was something. The characters are still great, Poirot being the best, but the story was weird as many reviewers have said already. Hastings was far less annoying in this one, especially since he's married so no more weird and annoying interactions with the female characters in the book. I actually didn't mind the idea of Poirot fighting against an international crime group. But the execution was rather odd. Some moments felt great, and very inline with Poirot. Others however, felt out of place and just didn't feel realistic. What makes Poirot, and Christie for that matter, is the realistic crimes which have well drawn and real characters who aren't perfect. It's not necessarily about Poirot outsmarting some supremely intelligent criminal a la Moriarty. He learns about all the characters, even the things they don't want to reveal, and puts the pieces together to understand who was capable of the crime and how they did it. Here though, there was just random things happening with no real thread to the overall plot and characters who only exist in the background. The story just feels out of place.

Quick hits:
+ Poirot as usual, still such an engaging character.
+ Hastings played an actual Watson role and wasn't annoying.
+ There were moments which felt great and inline with the series.
- The plot was very up and down.
- The story felt out of place, and too out there.

Overall, this wasn't the best. The writing and main characters were great as usual, but the rest not so much. I know we return to form in the rest of the series, and I'll definitely be continuing.

Title: Pride and Prejudice
Author: Jane Austen
My Review:
Nothing I say will be much different from the millions of others who have experienced Jane Austen. But wow was this great. I've seen most of the adaptations (I'm partial to the Laurence Olivier and the 1980s adaptation) and thoroughly enjoyed them. I figured I would finally delve into the actual book and it was well worth it. I'd like to rewatch the adaptations to see if my opinion changes, but I can definitely see why the 1995 adaptation is well regarded (which I still really like).

Austen is frankly timeless. Her plotting, her characters, her world are believable no matter when you read it. I truly believe anyone can read and enjoy Austen. I think what's so special about Pride and Prejudice is just how real it feels. The growth of the characters individually and their relationship feel so realistic and natural. There's a moment later in the book where there's a slow down in pace so the characters and story can take a breath and reflect. If you do the same as a reader, you'll see how far you've already journeyed with the characters and how much time you have left. I've read plenty of romance, and a lot of times it feels very quick or the story itself takes place in such a short amount of time. But not here, everything flows perfectly. It's simply a classic.

Quick hits:
- Reading after seeing an adaptation enhances the experience since you have visual representations in your mind already.
- I appreciated Jane much more in this, including her relationship with Elizabeth. In the adaptations, she tends to be somewhat of an afterthought in making Elizabeth the focus. But her secondary story is important and pivotal to Elizabeth.
- The relationship, the growth and the pivotal scenes were all perfect.
- Mr. Bennet definitely seems much more like a poor father than in some of the adaptations.
- Timeless classic.

What else is there to say, it's a classic for a reason. I've ordered the rest of Austen's work (which I've seen many more adaptations for) and I'm excited to continue exploring her important contributions to literary history. It's sad to think about that she never truly got to see her own success and how much her work has meant to generations of people.

My Review:
Now this is what I was looking for! If for some reason you read my review for book 1 in this series, my biggest struggle with the book was that it seemed like the story meandered for most of the book. It frankly didn't seem like it knew where it was going. That certainly is not the case here, which was my expectation after reading book 1 and some of the author's previous works.

Quick hits:
- Cassia and Leonidas have great chemistry and bounce so well off each other.
- Each of the side characters felt like they had purpose in the overall story, compared to book 1 where they felt shoehorned in.

- Development between Cassia and Leonidas was really enjoyable.
- The ending seems somewhat silly to me. I like the development for Leonidas but it's clearly not going to stay that way as it defeats the purpose of the series...

I did not get my resolution with Regulus as I would've liked, but he wasn't annoying in this book so I wasn't upset. I do wish the side characters had some larger roles as I'd like to learn more about them. Overall though, this was very enjoyable and I think it's a solid historical mystery. I'd recommend this to those who love the genre or the series. I'll be continuing when the next book is out.

Title: Hyperion (Hyperion Cantos, #1)
Author: Dan Simmons
My Review:
A mixed but enjoyable first foray into science fiction.

Quick hits:
- Interesting characters who don’t have the outcomes you’d expect.
- A ton of great world building, although as a first time sci-fi reader I was overwhelmed with all the unknown occasionally.
- The pacing was the biggest struggle for me. I don’t normally mind flashbacks but I really struggled with the flashback chapter storytelling in this. Some of them, for example the first, really dragged and felt they had a lot of fluff that wasn’t necessary. This is likely a personal preference though.
- Ending was not what I expected.

Overall, an enjoyable ride but I did struggle some throughout. I definitely will be trying sci-fi again in the future.

Title: Poirot Investigates (Hercule Poirot, #3)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
Another pleasant read for Papa Poirot. If you’ve seen David Suchet’s adaptations, you can picture the scenes and episodes while reading each stories. While this was still enjoyable, a good portion of the stories were a little too short to really have the impact they normally would.

Quick hits:
- So many memorable stories and cases. The last story “Chocolate Box” is one of my favorites.
- Much more focus on Poirot than on Hastings which was nice since Hastings was annoying in the last book.
- Stories we’re good, but a little too short and didn’t really marinate as much as I would’ve liked.
- A lot of great memories from these stories and proves David Suchet is the de facto adaptation.

Overall, I enjoyed this one, but it didn’t reach 5 stars this time (and that’s okay!). I’ll definitely be continuing in the series and I look forward to my next romp with Papa Poirot!

Title: Death in the Dark Walk (John Rawlings #1)
Author: Deryn Lake

Title: Billy Boyle (Billy Boyle World War II, #1)
Author: James R. Benn

Title: Blood of a Gladiator (Leonidas the Gladiator Mysteries, #1)
Author: Ashley Gardner
My Review:
3.5/5 rounded up to 4. I enjoyed my time with this one, and sets up some interesting characters to follow in the future, but this was a little too messy for me to give higher than 3.5 stars.

Quick hits:
- All of the main characters are interesting and are in a unique position which sets up some cool growth in the future.
- The mystery was...there? It meandered a lot and the plot didn't really seem like it knew where it wanted to go. It felt like it took until ~65% before the story figured out what it wanted to be. Once it was more focused, the mystery was solid.
- Awesome time period to explore.
- Regulus, Regulus, Regulus. I've read the author's Captain Lacey series and he's a very similar character to Colonel Brandon. My biggest gripe in that series was the drama and problems were dragged on far too long and didn't make for an enjoyable subplot for the main character. Regulus is similar to Brandon for Leonidas and I'm concerned it'll be the same format here. Things don't need to be resolved in 1 paragraph, but 5+ books is overkill.

As you can tell, I'm somewhat mixed. I enjoyed the characters, the time period and the story (once it figured out where to go), but, there was a lot that took away from the enjoyment too. The writing is solid and this is an okay start to a new series. I enjoyed the author's other series and I will be continuing to book 2 here.

Title: Past Crimes: A Compendium of Historical Mysteries
Author: Ashley Gardner

Title: The Irish Assassins: Conspiracy, Revenge and the Phoenix Park Murders that Stunned Victorian England
Author: Julie Kavanagh

Title: The Mysterious Affair at Styles (Hercule Poirot, #1)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
Another absolute banger by the Queen. Every time I'm finishing her books, I'm wondering why it took me my entire life to start reading her!

Quick hits:
- Poirot. Simple as that, if you love him, he's just as great here.
- All the characters are well written.
- The mystery is complex with multiple characters with a possible motive.
- Unexpected resolution.

Overall, another amazing read, 5/5 stars, highly recommend!

Title: The Courtship Dance: A Regency Romance (Matchmaker)
Author: Candace Camp
My Review:
This was a fun and quick read. Very solid from start to finish and none of the characters or plot ever got annoying/frustrating.

Quick hits:
- Characters were great.
- Pacing moved well, never felt like anything was drawn out or characters weren't speaking to each other.
- Great chemistry between the leads.
- Engaging dialogue that had a plethora of funny moments.
- The Perkins subplot got a little too obvious and silly at the end, but it was resolved quickly that you don't remember it much.

Overall, if you like historical, this would be a good one to pick up. 4/5 stars.

Title: The Murder on the Links (Hercule Poirot, #2)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
Another thoroughly enjoyable Christie, although I had to drop a star because some of that Hasting's plotline got rather annoying. I appreciate the foil that Hastings is meant to be for Poirot, but this was doing it a little too brown.

Quick hits:
- Poirot is Poirot. No matter where you step in he feels the same swell guy.
- Hastings plotline was just so unnecessary and annoying to be honest. Nevermind that it wasn't believable.
- The mystery is complex with so many possibilities and clues that are hard to keep track of, but a very solid resolution.
- Continue to be very, very quick reads. It's so easy to blaze through 50+ pages.

Overall, 4/5 stars, very enjoyable and I will be continuing onto the next Poirot adventure!

Title: The Murder of Roger Ackroyd (Hercule Poirot, #4)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
Another absolute banger. It’s so cliche to say since she’s one of the all time best sellers but Agatha Christie is still to this day on another level. Her character work, her mysteries, her writing are all top notch. I don’t know what took me so long to read her work but I won’t be stopping here.

Quick hits:
- Poirot is superb as usual. Great personality and adds so much to the story.
- Characters are great, Caroline was so fun every time she was on the page and I would read a story just with her in it.
- Unexpected twist and ending which dumb founded me and made such a satisfying conclusion.
- Classic style with engaging mystery, solid clues and a chance for the reader to discover the answer.

Although this one felt less daring the reader to figure it out, it had such a unique way of delivering the story and such an awesome plot, that it stayed amazing throughout. Another 5 stars from me as I continue to dig into the QUEEN’s backlist.

Title: Murder on the Orient Express (Hercule Poirot, #10)
Author: Agatha Christie
My Review:
I’ve done it, I finally read a book by the Queen of Mystery. And what a ride it was. I managed to stay unspoiled all my life, but regardless I would’ve enjoyed this no matter what. I’m not unfamiliar with Poirot, having seen a good chunk of the David Suchet adaptations, but I never watched any of this particular story. I’m so glad I did the book version first, and now I can watch the adaptation with full knowledge.

Quick hits:
- Poirot at his finest: methodical, smart, sardonic. I did miss having Hastings around.
- Engaging mystery with tons of clues and red herrings.
- A unique resolution and timeless story.
- Agatha Christie is the queen for a reason. Not only is she a talented writer, but throughout the story she’s practically daring the reader to figure it out. Clearly laying out the information and clues, saying: “Hey reader, can’t you see it? Can’t you see who did it?”
- The side helpers Buoc and the Doctor were fun and made for engaging Hastings like characters.

Overall, I know I’m very late to the party. But, this was a banger. I enjoyed it from start to finish and would highly, highly recommend to mystery fans. I will absolutely be going through the Queen’s backlist ASAP.

Title: No King, No Country (The Inness Legacy #1)
Author: Wayne Grant

Title: The Exploits and Adventures of Brigadier Gerard
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle

Title: The Eagle and the Raven (Rediscovered Classics)
Author: Pauline Gedge

Title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes (Sherlock Holmes, #3)
Author: Arthur Conan Doyle
My Review:
My first foray into true Sherlock fiction, and it was mostly an enjoyable experience. The short stories which really stuck to the investigation and Holmes’ deduction are the best.

Quick hits:
- A nice blend of crime types.
- Plenty of Holmes and Watson who just bounce so well off each other.
- Most short stories are great. There are a couple where there’s no investigation and Holmes’ just deduces in 2 seconds which were a lot less engaging.
- Every story even at ~20 pages felt juicy and not too short or long.
- Timeless writing, meaning even though this was written over 100 years ago, it felt like it could’ve come out as historical fiction yesterday.

Overall, I really enjoyed this and will continue my foray into the official Sherlock stories in the future. Highly recommend!

Title: The Stardust Thief (The Sandsea Trilogy #1)
Author: Chelsea Abdullah
My Review:
A really fun and enjoyable book that feels more real than fantasy.

Quick hits:
- Fun characters, and anyone who says Mazen isn’t the best is a liar.
- The world feels real and like I’m listening to someone tell me a story.
- The world is so well realized, I could feel the sand and desert.
- Nice intersperse of story in a story.

Overall, a really fun start to a new world. If you’re looking for what sounds like a story without an overly complex world or thousands of terms to learn, this is for you.

Title: The Fall (The Bound and the Broken, #0.5)
Author: Ryan  Cahill

Title: Death on the Sapphire (Lady Frances Ffolkes #1)
Author: R.J. Koreto

Title: Murder in Belgravia (A Mayfair 100 Murder Mystery #1)
Author: Lynn Brittney

Title: The Body in the Garden (Lily Adler Mystery, #1)
Author: Katharine Schellman

Title: Deception by Gaslight (A Gilded Gotham Mystery, #1)
Author: Kate Belli

Title: Absence of Mercy (A Lightner and Law Mystery #1)
Author: S.M. Goodwin

Title: Art in the Blood (Sherlock Holmes Adventures, #1)
Author: Bonnie MacBird
My Review:
A fun and enjoyable ride from start to finish. I don’t read much Sherlock (not sure why…) and saw this series in my local bookstore. I figured might as well give it a shot. Glad I did.

Quick hits:
- Sherlock and Watson seemed entirely like I expected them to.
- Case got more complex and crazy but fun the whole time.
- I enjoyed the side characters, especially the rivalry with Vidoc.
- Towards the end, I felt a little too much convenience in the story for Sherlock to figure it out but we then quickly jumped to the next so it wasn’t bothersome.

Overall, thoroughly enjoyed. I will definitely continue the series. 4/5 stars.

Title: The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi (Amina al-Sirafi, #1)
Author: Shannon Chakraborty

Title: Murder in the Crypt (Redmond and Haze Mysteries, #1)
Author: Irina Shapiro

Title: A Rip Through Time (A Rip Through Time, #1)
Author: Kelley Armstrong

Title: Letter from the Dead (Detective Inspector Declan Walsh #1)
Author: Jack Gatland

Title: Miss Morton and the English House Party Murder (Miss Morton Mysteries #1)
Author: Catherine Lloyd

Title: Stealing the Crown (A Guy Harford Mystery #1)
Author: T.P. Fielden

Title: The Man in the Queue (Inspector Alan Grant, #1)
Author: Josephine Tey

Title: Ask Me No Questions (Lady Dunbridge Mystery, #1)
Author: Shelley Noble

Title: The Sacred Band: Three Hundred Theban Lovers Fighting to Save Greek Freedom
Author: James Romm

Title: Singapore Sapphire (Harriet Gordon Mystery, #1)
Author: A.M.   Stuart
My Review:
I loved my time with this. Interesting characters, slowly revealed complex mystery and good setup for the future.

Quick hits:
- Characters have solid backstories which make them feel real and flawed.
- Plot starts narrow and slowly expands.
- The reveal felt somewhat unexpected and unpredictable which I didn’t really like as I didn’t have much of a chance to guess.
- Solid ending setup for the series.

Overall, I’m excited to continue reading more. The reveal was a little too unpredictable but still enjoyable overall.

Title: The Last Stand of Mary Good Crow (The Crystal Calamity, #1)
Author: Rachel Aaron

Title: Murder in Old Bombay (Captain Jim Agnihotri #1)
Author: Nev March

Title: Snowspelled (The Harwood Spellbook, #1)
Author: Stephanie Burgis
My Review:
A fun and quick ride. I was looking for something breezy as I’ve been struggling with a book funk recently and this was a good fit. Although fantasy, easily approachable and a light read.

Quick hits:
- Characters were fun and had good chemistry.
- Some predictable moments.
- Novella convenience where there’s just answers and resolution with little explanation.
- Light read and fast paced.

Overall I got out of it exactly what I needed. A fun, fast read but won’t knock your socks off.

Title: This is How You Lose the Time War
Author: Amal El-Mohtar

Title: Marion Lane and the Midnight Murder (Marion Lane, #1)
Author: T.A. Willberg

Title: Murder at Wedgefield Manor (A Jane Wunderly Mystery #2)
Author: Erica Ruth Neubauer
My Review:
I’m kind of settling at 4/5 here. There was some stuff that I really enjoyed but some that also took me out of the story.

Quick hits:
- Jane and Redvers are still great.
- A little too many “modern sensibilities” and a little too perfect of characters (being vague to avoid spoilers).
- Mystery was pretty predictable. Given the situation, very few realistic suspects and quite clear who the culprit was.
- The pacing was good and I felt the characters did a good job investigating.
- Still an enjoyable experience.

I struggled with this one. I still enjoyed it and settled at 4 stars. I got taken out of the story a bunch and there was a predictable ending. Would recommend if you’re a fan of the series.

Title: Murder at the Mena House (A Jane Wunderly Mystery #1)
Author: Erica Ruth Neubauer
My Review:
This was a fun read to get me back on the grind after a reading slump and being sick. 4/5 stars.

Quick hits:
- Fun characters with a good mix of personalities. Many played a role in the mystery in some form.
- Intriguing mystery.
- Well paced.
- Awesome setting.
- Some “modern” sensibilities but not so much to override the enjoyment.

A quick and fun read. It won’t knock your socks off but is an enjoyable experience from start to finish. Would recommend for mystery readers.

Title: A Botanist's Guide to Parties and Poisons (Saffron Everleigh Mystery, #1)
Author: Kate Khavari

Title: A Test of Wills (Inspector Ian Rutledge, #1)
Author: Charles Todd

Title: A Duty to the Dead (Bess Crawford, #1)
Author: Charles Todd

Title: The Redemption of Alexander Seaton (Alexander Seaton, #1)
Author: Shona MacLean

Title: The Bookseller of Florence: The Story of the Manuscripts That Illuminated the Renaissance
Author: Ross King

Title: Essex Dogs (Essex Dogs, #1)
Author: Dan Jones
Publisher: Head of Zeus -- an Aries Book

Title: Rise of the Mages (The Age of Ire, #1)
Author: Scott Drakeford

Title: The Last Smile in Sunder City (The Fetch Phillips Archives #1)
Author: Luke Arnold

Title: Miss Percy's Pocket Guide to the Care and Feeding of British Dragons (Miss Percy Guide, #1)
Author: Quenby Olson

Title: No Comfort for the Lost (Mystery of Old San Francisco, #1)
Author: Nancy Herriman
My Review:
This was a very solid mystery with interestingly a more classic noir feel.

Quick hits:
- Interesting mystery plot with a noir feel.
- The resolution was somewhat good. I guessed half of it but couldn’t really guess all of it considering the mystery’s restrictions. I’m being vague here for spoilers. Mystery is still good, it just would be hard to guess every detail.
- Characters are interesting and complex with their own backstories. They bounce off each other well.
- Good exploration of San Francisco in the time period.

I really enjoyed this one from start to finish. The characters felt flushed out and the mystery was complex and slowly unraveled through the story. I’m excited to continue the series.

Title: A Sleigh Ride Kiss (A Christmas Match, #2)
Author: Jen Geigle Johnson
My Review:
This one didn’t really do it for me. There were moments, especially in the first half where it felt good, but kind of fell apart for me in the second half.

Quick hits:
- Main characters have good chemistry.
- The main conflict drags on for far too long, especially considering all the characters but 1 are aware of it. The fact one of the main MCs didn’t figure it out sooner feels contrived.
- There are some out of character moments late in the book that took me out of it.
- The first half is a lot of fun.

I’m deliberately trying to be vague to avoid spoilers but this wasn’t as much of a fun, quick read as I thought it would be. Maybe I just wasn’t in the mood, but this was a miss for me.

Title: The Shadow of the Gods (The Bloodsworn Saga, #1)
Author: John Gwynne
My Review:
4.5/5 stars.

This was awesome. Exactly what I wanted from a fantasy book: good characters, interesting world, and great action.

Quick hits:
- Orka is legit the best character it’s not even close. She is complex, strong, and somewhat unpredictable.
- I’m kind of up and down on Elvar, she has good moments and then some where I’m like come on.
- Varg has great character development.
- Action is AWESOME. Really picks up in the second half.
- The world is clearly influenced from mythology yet feels unique and fresh. I’m interested to learn more about it.
- Great pacing.
- A couple of predictable moments but that’s going to happen.

Overall, I loved this. A few nitpicks that didn’t detract much from the story. Looking forward to book 2!

Title: Our Lady of Blades (Court of Shadows, #2)
Author: Sebastien de Castell

Title: The Angel's Mark (Nicholas Shelby #1)
Author: S.W. Perry
My Review:
4.25/5 stars.

I really enjoyed this one. It picked up significantly in the last third and brought this to 4.25. While there is definitely mystery central to the plot, I would classify this more as 60% historical fiction and 40% mystery. There’s a lot of great information about the time period and descriptions of London. The distinction of the percentages is important because the mystery doesn’t really get into gear for a while and you may be disappointed otherwise. The mystery was pretty solid overall.

Quick hits:
- Easily digestible prose, which makes for a fast read.
- Characters had to deal with complex decisions, although I did feel a couple of them didn’t marinate for long enough. Presented and then quickly resolved.
- One of the best descriptions of a place I’ve read. I could really picture London and especially the core places of the story.
- No character is perfect, all dealing with complex things that impact them. This makes for a more believable story.
- Some resolutions were a little too fast, as we weren’t dealing with a detective, I wish we spent more time considering options.

Overall, a good reading experience. I’m looking forward to the next book and would recommend for historical fiction and mystery fans.

Title: Mistborn: The Final Empire (Mistborn, #1)
Author: Brandon Sanderson
My Review:
4.5/5 stars.

I’m finally writing a review after almost a week. I needed time to digest this book. I really, really enjoyed this. There were parts I struggled through, but I’m happy I finished. I was worried this would fall flat considering the hype, but it didn’t!

Quick hits:
- As everyone says, a complex yet easy to understand magic system. Even the nicknames give a good idea of their role.
- Very interesting world. I found the politics and society really interesting. A play on classic court style.
- Great characters with depth, each getting their moment to play their role.
- I struggled with pacing in some sections. I don’t think this was the writing, but more so to do with me. It sometimes felt like start, stop, start stop.
- Some things I guessed and some I didn’t. I’m curious to see what happens in the rest of the series.

Overall, I really enjoyed this. It’s got what you want in the first book of a fantasy trilogy: interesting world, complex magic, approachable story and scope, cool characters, and plenty of action. Highly recommend.

Title: James Bond: The Complete Warren Ellis Omnibus
Author: Warren Ellis
My Review:
4/5 stars.

This was a lot of fun. Fast paced, action packed and full of classic Bond.

Quick hits:
- Feeling of a classic Bond movie.
- Crazy violence.
- Interesting plot that was modern but felt old school.
- Some of the quips and one liners were a little….out of place? They felt too modern and not something Bond would actually say, even the sarcastic ones.
- Fantastic art.

Overall, highly recommend for someone who likes Bond or is interested in a quick read.

Title: The Mozart Code
Author: Rachel McMillan
My Review:
4.25/5

I really enjoyed this a lot. There’s a lot going on in the first half of the book and then kicks into high gear after 50%. I have a couple of gripes but thoroughly enjoyed my time and experience with Simon and Sophie.

Quick hits:
- Simon and Sophie feel like real people that could’ve existed. Both grappling with their own demons as well as their relationship. Let me tell you, chapter 26 had the most tension and angst between two characters I’ve read in recent memory (I mean this in the best way).
- There a couple of moments which took me out of the story quickly like Simon putting his gun away and then two paragraphs later the same type of sentence occurs with no reference to his gun coming back out. Minor gripe.
- The very end resolved pretty quickly and left some things open I would’ve liked resolved. I’m assuming this may be to leave the door open for another book in this universe (like London Restoration).
- The scenery was described so well. I could imagine Vienna post world war 2, stuck in the middle of destruction and rebuilding.

Overall, I would highly recommend this, especially for fans of historical fiction. The world is well described, the characters are believable, and their journey throughout this book is the type you love to see in a relationship: emotion, angst, and happiness.

Title: The Shadow of the Wind (The Cemetery of Forgotten Books, #1)
Author: Carlos Ruiz Zafón

Title: Rebels, Vol. 2: These Free and Independent States
Author: Brian Wood
My Review:
Unfortunately didn’t work for me. There were a couple of good moments but not enough to be a truly enjoyable experience.

Quick hits:
- Art was mostly good, but there was a couple of places it was jarring. For example, Seth Allen in then Green Mountain Boys. His head seems way too large for the proportions of the rest of his body.
- A lot of jumping around. There were multiple cases I thought I was missing something but I wasn’t, we just randomly jumped to something else.
- Not enough dialogue or exposition, a lot of transition is told through confusing panels.
- Playing with history is fine but some of it was a little too out there. For example, the gold.

Overall, I guess if you’re really craving a historical fiction comic and ran out of other options, try this one. I’ve read a lot of comics but this one just didn’t do it for me. Lots of random jumps and not a lot of context given in certain scenes.

Title: Your Guide to Not Getting Murdered in a Quaint English Village
Author: Maureen Johnson

Title: Refining Lord Preston  (Proper Regency Matchmakers #6)
Author: Laura Beers
My Review:
A fun and breezy read.

Quick hits:
- Characters were fun and believable.
- Scenes between Isaac and has father mostly felt like they had no contribution to either character or the story.
- Isaac is pretty adamant about his decision when the eventual solution is pretty simplistic and is essentially the same idea.
- Side characters added to the story and I think reading about Hatch would be fun.

Overall, it’s a romance and it was a fun and quick read. Would recommend it for those reasons. Nothing to make it 4 or above for me, but that’s okay because it was solid and romances are usually 3-5 for me.

Title: The Justice of Kings (Empire of the Wolf, #1)
Author: Richard  Swan
My Review:
Awesome debut, 4.25/5 stars. Great writing, interesting characters, and discourse of themes.

Quick hits:
- The last 110 pages is super fast paced and felt like the best type of anarchy. So much happening on every page.
- The underlying discussion of not only justice, but how people are effected by that justice and how the events of our lives change our perception of justice was awesome.
- Interesting characters with interesting motivations.
- A solid mystery, but more importantly how that mystery plays into the future plot.
- Helena is an interesting POV character and gives us a truly unique view into the world. She plays well off of Vonvault and Bressinger (even Radomir).
- I felt sometimes Helena was a little too immature and petulant. The love story was honestly meh, not bad but just there. None of these are really too often or present and doesn’t take away from the story.
- Complex political landscape with a lot of moving pieces.

Overall, this is a great fantasy debut. I enjoyed my time reading it and would definitely recommend. Due to some of the stuff with Helena bringing me down slightly, and the mystery being resolved earlier than I was expecting, it wasn’t fully 5 stars. But still dope!

P.S. I would caution going into this book with no expectations. It’s getting comparisons to a lot of different things (which happens to every book), but I think going in blind is best. It has intrigue, action, suspense and more. But going in expecting too much of one thing may leave you disappointed.

Title: For Love or Honor (The Jonquil Brothers #5)
Author: Sarah M. Eden

Title: Darkness Forged (Legends of the Ragnarok Era, #1)
Author: Matt Larkin

Title: Hall of Bones (The Brotherhood of the Eagle, #1)
Author: Tim Hardie

Title: The Thief Who Pulled on Trouble's Braids (Amra Thetys, #1)
Author: Michael  McClung

Title: A River Enchanted (Elements of Cadence, #1)
Author: Rebecca   Ross
My Review:
This one was a struggle for me. There were sections I was really invested, but then sections where I wasn’t. This is more of a character and world driven story than plot driven. I went into this hoping to dig into a cool mystery (my favorite genre) with interesting characters in a cool world. I got some of that. The world is really really cool and it’s history and role in the story was awesome. The characters were kind of interesting. There were some common archetypes, but they each had a purpose and role to play so all the perspectives felt important. So why 2 stars? I think overall the weak mystery with predictable resolution and that honestly cheap ending settled it for me.

Quick hits:
- Good writing with short chapters (why can’t there be more of this in fantasy?)
- Interesting world which plays a huge part in the story
- Slow moving plot
- Okay mystery, the premise is interesting but it really is a backseat to the world and characters
- Out of character moments at the end of the book to purely setup a sequel (even more frustrating considering how central the characters and their relationships are to this entire book)

Overall, minus the ending, this still would’ve settled around a 3-3.5 for me. It’s not bad but it’s not good. The world is unique and so is it’s history and prevalence in the story, but the rest is just okay at best. The writing is good and very easily digestible, but couldn’t save the mystery’s resolution and what I felt was a cheap ending. If you’re interested in unique worlds, it may be worth a try for you. But I wouldn’t expect really complex characters or an immersive mystery. Those are secondary to the world.

Title: The Cater Street Hangman (Charlotte & Thomas Pitt, #1)
Author: Anne Perry
My Review:
3.5/5 rounded up. I enjoyed my experience reading the book overall, but it really was only okay. The writing was solid, plenty of characters, and a lot of relationships making the “world” feel full.

Quick hits:
- Not much mystery, more character focused with little plot.
- Too many perspective changes, I didn’t really care about what certain characters were thinking.
- A lot of drama which is tangentially related to the crime at best.
- Charlotte and Thomas were fun to watch interact and what I looked forward to the most.
- I wish Pitt was there more frequently.

If you’re interested in more of a period drama with the lightest hint of mystery, I’d recommend. But it’s completely in the background compared to the entirety of Charlotte’s family.

Title: Engines of Empire (The Age of Uprising, #1)
Author: Richard S. Ford

Title: The Butchering Art: Joseph Lister's Quest to Transform the Grisly World of Victorian Medicine
Author: Lindsey Fitzharris
Publisher: Scientific American / Farrar, Straus and Giroux

Title: The Spy Who Came In from the Cold (George Smiley, #3)
Author: John le Carré
My Review:
I unfortunately have to mark this one as spoilers. This book was such a tough one for me. It had the highest highs but some of the lowest lows. This book built tension and kept the reader guessing better than any book I’ve read. The amount of time I spent guessing whether or not Alec really was playing a role or falling into it was a lot. Most (emphasis on most) characters were awesome! Mundt, Fielder, Control and Alec were great. But boy oh boy did Liz suck. She was an absolute plant to drive the end of the story and that’s it. First off, of course she has to sleep with Alec because what else could a woman serve in a story right? Then, after spending essentially a small number of time together with little dialogue, I’m supposed to believe she’s in love with Alec. Seriously? Come on. At this point I’m thinking she just doesn’t have an important role (spoilers, I was wrong). She eventually gets a letter from the Centre which she clearly doesn’t think is real or a good idea to accept, but has to convince herself to accept because how else would the story get resolved? This was all a setup for her being the witness against Alec at the end. I was so aggravated at that point I didn’t even get a chance to appreciate an actual good plot twist! The ending for Alec was a good bookend but a lot of that last section sucked because of the shoehorning of Liz’s character. When she gets the letter, she clearly displays she’s an intelligent character (which is honestly great because we need more well written female characters in fiction) but Carre had to essentially just push her character against herself to get her where she needed to be for the climax and resolution. All of this and nevermind the fact that Alec who’s a seasoned spy with an agreed upon elaborate plan to take down Mundt decides as all men, he can’t keep it in his pants so he sleeps with a random woman. I get this is a product of its time, but for me it didn’t excuse some of the blaring problems.

So how is this 3 stars after this rant? Because the rest was sooooooo good. The tension, the story, the villains and antagonists felt real and well developed. I felt what it would’ve been like in the Cold War. I enjoyed all of that so much, it salvages the rating and book for me. I’ll still be checking out Carre’s other works (I really like Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy), but this one kind of sits in the middle for me.

Overall, I’d still recommend if you like suspense and spy thrillers. The stuff I mentioned probably won’t bother others as much.

Title: Heir of Novron (The Riyria Revelations, #5-6)
Author: Michael J. Sullivan
My Review:
Wow. Wow. Wow. 6 books in a row with incredible act 3s. Loved this book so much. I laughed, felt sorrow and joy. I’m sad to see it’s over but glad I went for the ride.

Quick hits:
- So many deaths and some unexpected, I was on the edge of my seat to see who’d survive.
- While I predicted a couple of the big reveals, it was really only right before we found out.
- The reveal of the history of the first empire was awesome.
- Royce, Hadrian, Modina, Arista, Mauvin, Alric, Myron, Nimbus, I will miss you all so much. Especially Myron, he’s the absolute GOAT.
- Great fights.
- Book 6‘s last 250 pages was filled with intensity, tension, and not put down-able. I read it in one sitting.
- A lot of great themes are explored.

Overall, highly recommend to fantasy fans. Starts small and gradually gets more epic every book. Each character grows and is given time in the spotlight. While there are moments for every emotion (positive and negative), it’s such good fun and a ride you’ll always remember.

Title: Rise of Empire (The Riyria Revelations, #3-4)
Author: Michael J. Sullivan
My Review:
Why the decrease in stars? There were 2 character related things done that I found really annoying or cringe but it’s personal preference so it may not bother everyone. Story is gaining ground rapidly, characters each have a stake in the story and the world is becoming much more formed.

Quick hits:
- Wow, totally unexpected character deaths.
- Great character development for Royce and Hadrian.
- Great growth for antagonists. Loved getting to spend time being more involved in their story.
- Strong female characters, we love it!
- I feel much more invested in the world and it’s history.
- Awesome journey and change of scenery.
- Sullivan writes nonstop act 3s.

I really loved this one, but the negative things (preferences from me) took me out of this omnibus twice and made this one more of a slog to get through. Still great though, on to the conclusion!

Title: Theft of Swords (The Riyria Revelations, #1-2)
Author: Michael J. Sullivan
My Review:
Absolutely awesome. Royce and Hadrian are great, and I really appreciated the development of secondary characters like Alric. He didn’t start as unlikeable per se, but he ended as a character I’d like to see more of in the future. Excited for more.

Quick hits:
- Characters actually displaying their abilities on screen and not just being told? Absolutely.
- Royce and Hadrian banter is great, but their chemistry is so fun to watch.
- Great third acts.
- Heists? Y-E-S!

Highly recommend to fantasy lovers, especially those who care about good characters and slow burn storytelling.

My Review:
I enjoyed this book so much, I’m writing my first Goodreads review!

To start, I haven’t read the other books in this series (only the first 3 are on Kindle?). Sometimes I like to start after the first couple books in a series to see if I like the writing and characters minus some of the early setup and character development (I go back and read the previous books after!).

This book starts off as a seemingly very small and easy mystery but quickly grows into something much larger. It involves a murder that’s steeped in the politics of the time. My only real criticism of this book was the length of the mystery. The suspect pool is small and while the resolution was great and made sense, it was still very easy to guess as it realistically could only have been less than a handful of people.

The biggest strength to me in this book was the characters and the balance between their stories. St. Mars and Mrs. Kean have their own plot lines which do overlap, but are also separate. It felt like they were two characters who were experiencing their own lives but existing in the same story. In many mysteries, this isn’t the case. The two main characters typically spend all their time together and while they have backstories, that’s all they are, backstories. This actually felt like I was experiencing two people who have backstories but have ongoing stories as well.

Overall, I loved this book. It was well researched and well written. I would recommend this to any fan of mystery. I can’t wait to read the other books!
